questions.text:
The molecular layer of cerebellum is made of? 
(i) Single row of Purkinje cells 
(ii) Stellate cells 
(iii) Basket cells 
(iv) Granular cells
questions.solution:
The molecular layer of the cerebellum primarily contains:

  • Stellate cells
  • Basket cells

These are the inhibitory interneurons that make connections in the molecular layer. The Purkinje cells are located in the Purkinje cell layer, not the molecular layer, and the granular cells are found in the granular layer, which is deeper.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 335, 336

questions.text: Hemiballismus is caused by lesion in which part of brain?
questions.solution:
• Wild, uncontrolled movements of one arm or one leg are signs of hemiballismus. The limbs move in an unwanted, ballistic, and failing manner. It is caused due to lesion in sub thalamic nucleus.
 
  • Hemiballismus is a hyperkinetic movement disorder characterized by sudden, violent, and involuntary flinging movements, typically involving one side of the body (contralateral to the brain lesion).
 
  • It is most commonly caused by a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus of the basal ganglia, often due to a stroke.
  • The subthalamic nucleus plays a critical role in the indirect pathway of the basal ganglia, which helps suppress unwanted movements.
  • Damage to this structure results in disinhibition of motor activity, leading to the uncontrollable movements seen in hemiballismus.


Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 367-370.

questions.text:
Which of the following are branches of posterior division of internal iliac artery?
(i) Inf. Vesical artery 
(ii) Inf. Gluteal artery 
(iii) Sup. Gluteal artery 
(iv) Lateral sacral artery
questions.solution:
Three branches of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery include:
  1. iliolumbar artery
  2. lateral sacral artery
  3. superior gluteal artery

Branches of Anterior division of Internal iliac artery:
 
  1. Umbilical artery
  2. Obturator artery 
  3. superior vesical artery
  4. Inferior vesical artery (in males) / Vaginal artery (in females)
  5. Uterine artery (in females)
  6. Middle rectal artery
  7. Internal pudendal artery
  8. Inferior gluteal artery

questions.text: Due to the rupture of the bulbar urethra, urine enters all these spaces except?
questions.solution:
When the bulbar urethra ruptures, typically due to trauma, urine can extravasate into the superficial perineal pouch. From there, it can spread to the following areas:

  • Scrotum
  • Penis
  • Anterior abdominal wall (beneath Scarpa's fascia)

However, urine does not enter the deep perineal space, as the deep perineal fascia (also called the perineal membrane) acts as a barrier separating the superficial and deep perineal compartments.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42nd edition, Page no 1299, 1255, 1256.

questions.text: Burnt sugar smell of urine is due to the defect of?
questions.solution:
The "burnt sugar" or "maple syrup" smell of urine is characteristic of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD).

  • This condition is caused by a defect in the enzyme branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase (BCKD), which is involved in the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine) i.e decarboxylation of the alpha-keto acids of leucine, isoleucine, and valine to their respective branched-chain acyl-CoAs.
 
  • The deficiency leads to the accumulation of these amino acids and their corresponding keto acids, resulting in the distinctive odor and neurological symptoms if untreated.



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 708, 709.

questions.text: The significance of HMP shunt are all except?
questions.solution:
The hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), is a metabolic pathway that occurs in the cytoplasm and serves several important functions. However, it does not generate ATP.

The hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway, is crucial for several reasons and has the following functions:

  1. NADPH Production: The pathway generates NADPH, which is essential for anabolic reactions, including fatty acid and cholesterol synthesis, and for maintaining the reduced state of glutathione in cells.
  2. Ribose-5-Phosphate Generation: It produces ribose-5-phosphate, 5 carbon sugar -a precursor for nucleotide and nucleic acid synthesis, which is vital for cell division and growth.
  3. Antioxidant Defense: NADPH produced by the HMP shunt helps regenerate reduced glutathione, a key antioxidant that protects cells from oxidative stress.
Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 146.

questions.text: A young male with a H/O dyslipidemia having ABCA-1 mutation shows the following see the image and tell diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Enlarged and yellowish/ Orange tonsils are pathognomonic of Tangier's disease.
 

Tangier disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ABCA1 gene. The ABCA1 protein is critical for the transport of cholesterol and phospholipids to apolipoprotein A-I (ApoA-I), which is essential for the formation of high-density lipoprotein (HDL).

Key features of Tangier disease:

  • Extremely low or absent HDL cholesterol levels ("hypoalphalipoproteinemia").
  • Accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues, leading to enlarged, orange-colored tonsils, hepatosplenomegaly, and peripheral neuropathy.
  • Increased risk of atherosclerosis despite low levels of circulating cholesterol.



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 258.

questions.text: Cystic fibrosis is caused by which of the following deletion?
questions.solution:

  • The second most common mutation is the G551D mutation caused by the substitution of the glycine by aspartate at position 551.

questions.text: Zellweger's syndrome is caused by defect of?
questions.solution:
• Zellweger syndrome belongs to a group of diseases called peroxisome biogenesis disorders (PBD). The diseases are caused by defects in any one of the PEX genes that are required for the normal formation and function of peroxisomes.

Zellweger syndrome is a rare congenital disorder caused by mutations in genes responsible for peroxisome biogenesis (commonly the PEX genes). These genes encode proteins essential for the formation and function of peroxisomes, which play a critical role in lipid metabolism and detoxification of hydrogen peroxide.


Clinical features:

  • Severe hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome).
  • Craniofacial abnormalities (high forehead, broad nasal bridge).
  • Hepatomegaly.
  • Developmental delay and seizures.
  • Early death, often within the first year of life.

The underlying defect is the inability to form functional peroxisomes, leading to the accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) and other toxic metabolites.



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 215, 579.

questions.text: SARS-COV2 diagnosis can be done by all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Southern blot is used for DNA detection and hence cannot be used for the detection of an RNA virus. Rest ( RT-PCR, Real-Time PCR, and Immunoassays) can be used for SARS-COV2 diagnosis. 
 

  • RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction): This is the most widely used and gold-standard method for diagnosing SARS-CoV-2. It detects viral RNA.

  • Real-Time PCR: A specific type of PCR that provides quantitative detection of viral RNA in real-time.

  • Immunoassays: These detect antibodies (serology) or antigens of SARS-CoV-2, commonly used for evaluating exposure or infection history.

  • Southern blot: This technique is used to detect DNA sequences, not RNA. Since SARS-CoV-2 is an RNA virus, Southern blot is not applicable for its diagnosis.




Reference: Freeman, Brandi et al. “Validation of a SARS-CoV-2 spike protein ELISA for use in contact investigations and serosurveillance.” bioRxiv : the preprint server for biology 2020.04.24.057323. 25 Apr. 2020, doi:10.1101/2020.04.24.057323. Preprint. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7239067/

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1512.

questions.text: 2,3, BPG causes unloading of oxygen to tissues by?
questions.solution:
• 2,3-BPG causes unloading of oxygen to tissues by binding to the central cavity of Hb surrounded by Histidine & lysine & favors salt bridge formation
 

  • 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) is a key regulator of oxygen delivery by hemoglobin (Hb). It binds to the central cavity of deoxyhemoglobin (taut or T-state) through interactions with positively charged residues, primarily histidine and lysine.

    This binding stabilizes the T-state of hemoglobin, which has a lower affinity for oxygen, thereby facilitating oxygen release (unloading) to the tissues. The presence of 2,3-BPG shifts the oxygen dissociation curve of hemoglobin to the right, meaning more oxygen is released at a given partial pressure.



Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 630-632.

questions.text: Fructosamine is the glycated product of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Fructosamine is the glycated product of albumin.
 
  • Fructosamine refers to glycated serum proteins, of which albumin is the most abundant.


Clinical Use:

  • Useful for monitoring glycemic control in conditions where HbA1c measurements are unreliable, such as:
    • Hemoglobinopathies (e.g., sickle cell anemia, thalassemia).
    • Conditions with altered red cell turnover (e.g., anemia, recent blood loss).
    • Pregnancy, where shorter-term glucose monitoring is important.
  • May also be used in gestational diabetes and rapidly changing glucose control settings.
  • It will give us the glycemic control of the last 3 weeks



Reference: Gounden V, Ngu M, Anastasopoulou C, et al. Fructosamine. [Updated 2023 Aug 14]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470185/

questions.text: The blue curve 'X' in the picture below depicts:
questions.solution:
Blue curve 'X' (Rectilinear Hyperbola) is due to myoglobin.
Since 1 myoglobin binds 1 molecule of O2 the shape is not sigmoid.
 

  1. Hyperbolic Shape:

    • The curve is steep, indicating that myoglobin binds to oxygen with high affinity, even at relatively low oxygen concentrations.
    • This high affinity means that once myoglobin binds to oxygen, it holds onto it strongly.

  2. Oxygen Affinity:

    • Myoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen compared to hemoglobin. This allows it to effectively pick up oxygen from hemoglobin in the muscle tissue and store it for use during periods of low oxygen availability (e.g., during exercise).

  3. Saturation:

    • Myoglobin is almost fully saturated with oxygen at normal physiological partial pressures of oxygen (around 20–40 mmHg). This makes it efficient for oxygen storage in muscle tissue.
    • It does not exhibit the cooperative binding behavior seen in hemoglobin, meaning each molecule binds oxygen independently without affecting others.

  4. P50 (Partial Pressure of Oxygen at 50% Saturation):

    • The P50 for myoglobin is low (around 2–3 mmHg), which means it will become 50% saturated at a low oxygen pressure. In comparison, hemoglobin’s P50 is around 26 mmHg.


Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 548, 631, 632, 640, 641.

questions.text: Least A-V difference is seen in?
questions.solution:
• The correct option is 3. Kidney.
 
  • The A-V difference refers to the difference in oxygen concentration between arterial (A) blood and venous (V) blood. The A-V difference is a measure of how much oxygen is extracted from the blood by the tissues. The greater the A-V difference, the more oxygen is extracted by the tissues.
 
  • The kidney has the least A-V difference among the options given. This is because the kidney requires a constant supply of blood to maintain its metabolic processes, and it extracts only a small amount of oxygen from the blood.
 
  • The brain and liver have a higher A-V difference because they require more oxygen for their metabolic processes.
 
  • The skin also has a higher A-V difference because it plays a role in temperature regulation, which requires significant oxygen consumption.



Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 590, 666.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used for mucociliary clearance?
questions.solution:
Saccharide clearance test, gamma scintigraphy and charcoal test can be used for examination of mucociliary clearance.
 

  • Saccharide test: This test is used to assess mucociliary clearance, as it involves the administration of a saccharide solution and then measuring the time it takes for it to be cleared from the airway.

  • CXR (Chest X-ray): While not the primary method, a chest X-ray may be used to assess for structural abnormalities or conditions that could affect mucociliary clearance (e.g., chronic lung diseases). It is not a direct test for mucociliary clearance but can provide useful context.

  • Scintigraphy: This is a specialized imaging test that is used to directly assess mucociliary clearance. It involves the use of a radioactive tracer that is inhaled and its movement in the airways is tracked over time.

  • Electron microscopy: This technique is used for examining the ultrastructure of cells and tissues at very high magnification but is not used for directly assessing mucociliary clearance. It can be useful in diagnosing conditions like primary ciliary dyskinesia, but it is not a test for mucociliary clearance itself.

Thus, electron microscopy is not used for assessing mucociliary clearance.



Reference: Cumming's Otorhinolaryngology: Head and Neck Surgery, 6th edition, Page no 54, 55.

questions.text: 2,3-BPG decrease the affinity of Hb to oxygen by binding to which chain?
questions.solution:
• 2,3-DPG acts as an allosteric regulator of hemoglobin in the RBC. When 2,3-DPG is bound to beta chains of hemoglobin, it stabilizes the T-state conformation and decreases hemoglobin affinity for oxygen.
 
  • 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) binds to the beta chains of deoxyhemoglobin (the T-state of hemoglobin). This binding stabilizes the T-state, which has a lower affinity for oxygen, thus promoting oxygen release in tissues.
 
  • 2,3-BPG does not bind to the alpha chains but rather to the positively charged residues in the central cavity of the hemoglobin tetramer, which is primarily formed by the beta chains. This decreases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen and facilitates oxygen unloading in peripheral tissues.



Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 630-632.

questions.text:
Iron overload in body detected by: 
(i) Heart iron level by scan 
(ii) Liver load 
(iii) Ferritin 
(iv) DMT-1
questions.solution:
DMT-1 is an iron transporter that moves Fe+2 and other bivalent ions from the luminal side of the intestine to the enterocytes and it is not specific for Fe+2
Rest 3 options can be used to detect iron overload in the body
 

Iron overload in the body can be detected by the following:

  1. Heart iron level by scan (i): Cardiac MRI with T2* imaging is used to measure iron deposition in the heart, especially in conditions like thalassemia or hemochromatosis.

  2. Liver load (ii): The liver is a primary site of iron storage, and liver iron concentration (LIC) can be measured via MRI or liver biopsy to assess iron overload.

  3. Ferritin (iii): Serum ferritin levels are often elevated in iron overload conditions and serve as an indirect marker of iron stores. However, it can also be elevated in inflammation or other conditions.

(iv) DMT-1 (Divalent Metal Transporter-1) is not used to detect iron overload. It is a protein involved in iron absorption and transport, but it is not a diagnostic marker.



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 655-657.

questions.solution:
• Macula densa is a part of JG apparatus and it is present in ascending limb of loop of Henle & DCT.
 
  • The macula densa is a specialized group of cells located in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) near its junction with the thick ascending loop of Henle.
 
  • These cells are part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus and play a critical role in regulating kidney function, particularly in sensing sodium concentration and helping regulate glomerular filtration rate (GFR) through tubuloglomerular feedback.

questions.text: Which molecule helps in movement of leucocytes across endothelial cells?
questions.solution:
Diapedesis or transmigration of leucocytes is mediated by PECAM/CD31.
 

PECAM-1 (CD31) is the key molecule involved in the transmigration (diapedesis) of leukocytes across endothelial cells. It is expressed on both leukocytes and endothelial cells, facilitating the movement of leukocytes through the endothelial barrier into tissues during inflammation.


Other options:

  • E-Selectin (Option 2):  Facilitates the rolling of leukocytes on the endothelial surface, an early step in the leukocyte extravasation process.
 
  • CD11a (Option 3): Part of the LFA-1 integrin, involved in firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium.
 
  • VLA-4 (Option 4): An integrin involved in leukocyte adhesion to endothelial cells and migration, particularly in certain tissues, but not directly responsible for transmigration.



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 12, 78, 79.

choices.text: 8g/dl, MCV=56, MCH =22, RBC count=5.5 million cumm

questions.text:
A 10 year old boy with Hb-9.8g/dl, MCV=56, MCH =22, RBC count=5.5 million cumm
Ferritin =150 [(N)-130-160],
TLC=7600; Lymphocyte = 65%, Neutrophil -30% 
What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the iron profile is suggestive of diagnosis of thalassemia.

 
  • The first difference in thalassemia and iron deficiency anemia is in the red blood cell count.
  • In iron deficiency, this value is low because the bone marrow is unable to manufacture red blood cells. In thalassemia trait, RBC is normal to elevated.
 
  • Mentzer index= MCV/RBC count
  • Here, Mentzer index= 9.8, which is less than 13, s/o Thalassemia trait
Mentzer index:
<13: Thalassemia trait/minor
>13: IDA

questions.text: Maximum amplitude in thromboelastography is due to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Platelets 

Thromboelastography provides information on the kinetics and strength of clot formation, which is represented by several parameters including maximum amplitude (MA).
 
  • The extrinsic pathway is responsible for initiating the clotting cascade in response to tissue injury.
  • The extrinsic pathway plays a crucial role in the initiation of clot formation, and therefore, it is responsible for the maximum amplitude in thromboelastography. 
  • Maximum Amplitude represents the maximal clot strength, which is primarily influenced by the platelet function and count.
  • LY30 represents the percentage decrease in amplitude at 30 min after MA was reached, and reflects fibrinolysis.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1161.

Shaydakov ME, Sigmon DF, Blebea J. Thromboelastography. [Updated 2023 Apr 10]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537061/

questions.text: Senile atrophy is due to?
questions.solution:
Senile atrophy in brain is seen due to atherosclerotic changes leading to ischemia.
 

Atrophy refers to the reduction in the size of a tissue or organ due to a decrease in cell size and number. It represents a form of cellular adaptation. This process involves reduced synthesis of cellular proteins and increased protein degradation, primarily through the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway.

Atrophy can be classified as either physiological or pathological:

Physiological atrophy:

  1. Loss of hormonal stimulation: Examples include uterine atrophy after childbirth and atrophy of the endometrium, vaginal epithelium, and breast tissue following menopause.
  2. During embryonic development: Structures such as the notochord and thyroglossal duct undergo atrophy during fetal development.

Pathological atrophy:
 
  1. Disuse atrophy (decreased workload): For instance, muscle atrophy in an immobilized limb after a fracture.
  2. Denervation atrophy (loss of nerve supply): For example, skeletal muscle atrophy following nerve damage.
  3. Ischemic atrophy: Seen in conditions like senile atrophy of the brain and heart due to atherosclerosis.
  4. Inadequate nutrition: Such as severe muscle wasting observed in marasmus.
  5. Pressure atrophy: For instance, atrophy of tissues surrounding a benign tumor due to sustained pressure.


Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 59, 60.

questions.text: Which of the following markers will be positive in Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
• Reed-Sternberg cells are large, abnormal lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell) that may contain more than one nucleus. These cells are found in people with Hodgkin lymphoma

questions.text: Absent graft versus host reaction in a patient with Bare lymphocyte disease is due to the deficiency of?
questions.solution:
Mutation in transcription factor that regulates the expression of class II MHC genes leads to absent graft vs host reaction.
 

Bare lymphocyte syndrome (BLS) is a rare immunodeficiency disorder characterized by the absence or reduced expression of MHC molecules on the surface of antigen-presenting cells (APCs).

  • In MHC class II deficiency, there is an inability to present antigens to CD4+ T cells, leading to impaired activation of these cells. This results in a lack of a graft-versus-host (GVH) reaction because CD4+ T cells play a central role in initiating GVH responses.

  • MHC I deficiency, on the other hand, would primarily affect the activation of CD8+ T cells and is associated with different immune defects.


Other options:

  1. CD4 T-cells: While their activation is impaired due to MHC II deficiency, the root cause in BLS is the lack of MHC II, not the absence of CD4 T-cells.
  2. Complement: Complement deficiencies affect innate immunity and are unrelated to GVH reactions or MHC expression.
  3. MHC I: Deficiency of MHC I primarily impacts CD8+ T cells and cytotoxic immune responses, not CD4-mediated processes.


Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 244.

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines are not released by Th1?
questions.solution:
Th1 cells primarily produce cytokines involved in cell-mediated immunity and the activation of macrophages, such as:

  • IFN-γ (Interferon-gamma): A key cytokine released by Th1 cells to activate macrophages and enhance the killing of intracellular pathogens.
  • IL-2: Promotes the proliferation of T cells.
  • TGF-β (Transforming Growth Factor-beta): Can be involved in immunoregulation but is not uniquely characteristic of Th1 cells.
  • IL-12: Not directly released by Th1 cells but promotes the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells.
T Helper cells are of 3 types - TH1 , TH2 and TH3 
1. Th1 takes part in cell mediated immunity - involves IL2, IL12 and INF gamma
2. Th2 takes part in Type 1 hypersensitivity - involves IL4, IL5 and IL 13 involved in activation of mast cells, eosinophils.
3. Th3 - IL 17 mediated

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 99.

questions.text: Match the following - Method of collecting the sample
questions.solution:
• Marjolin ulcer on the foot (3x2 cm) can be diagnosed by a wedge biopsy, which involves removing a small wedge-shaped piece of tissue for examination. Wedge biopsy is usually performed for lesions where not only length and breadth but also depth of specimen is important like Marjolin ulcer/subcutaneous mycosis etc.
 
  • Sarcoma on the thigh (8x4 cm) can be diagnosed by using a core needle biopsy, which involves inserting a larger needle into the nodule to collect a sample of tissue. A small and superficial tumor(<2 cm) could be diagnosed with an excision biopsy but for large tumors - A core needle is preferred. 
 
  • A single cervical lymph node (1.5x 2 cm) can be diagnosed by excisional biopsy. It is the appropriate method for collecting a sample in this case, as it involves removing the entire node and the entire nodal architecture can be seen for an appropriate diagnosis. 
 
  • Solitary nodules on the thyroid can be diagnosed by using a fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) guided by ultrasound.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 235, 741, 809, 862.

questions.text: Mass in stomach, CD117 positive but cytokeratin (CK), S100 negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A mass in the stomach that is CD117 (c-KIT) positive but cytokeratin (CK) and S100 negative strongly suggests a diagnosis of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST).

IHC markers:
  • CD117 (c-KIT): A marker characteristic of GISTs, found in the interstitial cells of Cajal or their precursors.
  • Cytokeratin (CK): Typically positive in carcinomas, such as adenocarcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma, but negative in GISTs.
  • S100: A marker for melanomas and neural tumors but is not associated with GISTs.

Other options:
 
  • Adenocarcinoma: (Option 2) Typically positive for cytokeratin.1
  • Hodgkin's lymphoma: (Option 3) Usually shows markers like CD15 and CD30, not CD117.
  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma: (Option 4)Typically positive for cytokeratin but not CD117.

Thus, the combination of CD117 positivity and CK/S100 negativity is characteristic of GIST.



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 778, 779.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true? 
(i) GIST : KIT 
(ii) Lung carcinoma : K-Ras-amplification 
(iii) Breast carcinoma : ERBB 
(iv) Astrocytoma : PDGFR-beta
questions.solution:
• Astrocytoma is associated with overexpression of PDGF-beta, NOT PDGFR-beta.
  • PDGFR-beta amplification is associated with Glioma and Leukemia.
 

  1. GIST : KIT (i)
    True. Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are commonly associated with mutations in the KIT gene, which encodes for the CD117 (c-KIT) receptor tyrosine kinase.

  2. Lung carcinoma : K-Ras amplification (ii)
    Partially true. While K-Ras mutations are frequently observed in lung adenocarcinoma, amplification of K-Ras is also seen in 30% of cases of Adenocarcinoma.

  3. Breast carcinoma : ERBB (iii)
    True. ERBB2 (HER2), a member of the EGFR family, is frequently amplified in certain subtypes of breast carcinoma, driving tumor growth and progression.




Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 285, 287, 717, 779, 813, 814, 1046.

questions.text: IHC for P40 positive with HPE slide as given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The IHC marker and the given image showing Keratin pearls are suggestive of Squamous cell carcinoma of lungs.

Different types of Lung carcinoma:

questions.text: In a patient with megaloblastic anaemia, which of the following sites is least likely to be associated with malabsorption/dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is Option (2)

Megalobloastic anemia occurs due to either Vit B12 or folate deficiency. Duodenum(option 2) is not involved in the absorption of vitamin B12 or folic acid. Folate is absorbed in the jejunum while B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Stomach secretes intrinsic factor involved in B12 Absorption and hence stomach dysfunction/involvement by a systemic illness can also result in B12 deficiency. 

Duodenum is involved in the absorption of iron, not B12/Folic acid and duodenal pathology can cause IDA (Iron deficiency anemia) but not megaloblastic anaemia. 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 651-654.

questions.text: A chronic smoker with a history of consuming 24 packs in a month presents with breathlessness and chest pain. On investigation, the lung tumor is found to stain positive for chromogranin. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Positivity for chromogranin points toward a diagnosis of Small cell carcinoma. Small cell carcinoma also has the strongest association with smoking (given in clinical stem)
 
Small cell carcinoma (SCLC) is strongly associated with heavy smoking and frequently presents with symptoms like breathlessness, chest pain, and other systemic manifestations. The staining for chromogranin indicates a neuroendocrine tumor, a hallmark feature of small cell carcinoma.

Features:
 
  1. Smoking History: SCLC has a strong association with chronic smoking.
  2. Neuroendocrine Markers: SCLC stains positive for markers like:
    • Chromogranin
    • Synaptophysin
    • CD56
  3. Clinical Presentation:
    • Rapidly growing central lung tumor.
    • Associated with symptoms due to bronchial obstruction or paraneoplastic syndromes (e.g., SIADH, ACTH secretion).

Other options:
 
  1. Squamous Cell Carcinoma: Typically stains positive for p63 and p40, not chromogranin.
  2. Adenocarcinoma: Commonly stains positive for TTF-1 and Napsin A, not chromogranin.
  3. Large Cell Carcinoma: Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma can stain for chromogranin, but it is rare and less strongly associated with smoking compared to SCLC.

Thus, the clinical history and chromogranin positivity strongly indicate Small Cell Carcinoma.



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 329, 716-722.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about sirtuins are true? 
(i) \(\uparrow\) insulin sensitivity and thus glucose metabolism 
(ii) Promote genes that increase longevity 
(iii) 7 types 
(iv) It's a type of histone deacetylase
questions.solution:
• Sirtuins are a family of signaling proteins involved in metabolic regulation.
  • All the above statements regarding sirtuins are true.


Functions of Sirtuins:
 
  1. Regulation of aging and longevity
  2. Metabolic regulation
  3. Stress resistance
  4. Regulation of inflammation
  5. Epigenetic regulation
  6. Mitochondrial function and biogenesis
  7. Regulation of apoptosis
  8. Cancer suppression and tumor progression
  9. Cardiovascular health
  10. Neuroprotection


Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 68.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Hemophilia A?
questions.solution:
Hemarthrosis and muscle hematoma are the features associated with Hemophilia A.
 

Hemophilia A is a bleeding disorder caused by Factor VIII deficiency and has the following characteristics:

  1. Factor 8 deficiency (True): Hemophilia A is due to a deficiency or dysfunction of Factor VIII, a key clotting factor in the intrinsic pathway.
  2. XLR inheritance (True): It is inherited in an X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern, primarily affecting males, while females are typically carriers.
  3. More common in males (True): Due to its X-linked inheritance, it predominantly occurs in males.
  4. Mucosal bleeding seen frequently (False): Mucosal bleeding is more characteristic of platelet disorders (e.g., von Willebrand disease or thrombocytopenia). In hemophilia A, the bleeding tends to involve joints (hemarthrosis), muscles, and soft tissues, rather than mucosal surfaces.

  • Hemophilia A typically presents with deep bleeding (e.g., joint and muscle hematomas), not superficial or mucosal bleeding.
  • Mucosal bleeding is more commonly associated with primary hemostasis disorders, like von Willebrand disease.



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 668, 669.

choices.text: At least 26 percent cases have family history
GB stones develop by 4 to 5 years age
Splenetomy doesn't protect against developing GB stones

questions.text: Which of the following is true in Hereditary Spherocytosis?
questions.solution:
People usually inherit hereditary spherocytosis from their parents. Usually, 1 parent has the disorder and there is a 50% chance of passing it on in each pregnancy
 

  1. At least 26 percent cases have family history (True):
    Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an autosomal dominant disorder in most cases, though autosomal recessive forms exist. A significant proportion of cases (Almost 75% cases) have a positive family history.

  2. High MCH pathognomonic (False):
    High mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) may be seen in HS due to cellular dehydration but is not specific or pathognomonic. It can occur in other conditions like dehydration or other hemolytic anemias.

  3. GB stones develop by 4 to 5 years age (False):
    Gallstones in HS result from chronic hemolysis and the subsequent increase in bilirubin levels. They typically develop later in childhood or adolescence, not as early as 4–5 years of age.

  4. Splenectomy doesn't protect against developing GB stones (False):
    Splenectomy reduces hemolysis, lowering bilirubin production, and thus reduces the risk of gallstone formation. However, it does not entirely eliminate the risk if gallstones have already formed.


    Hereditary Spherocytosis:

  • Pathophysiology: Defects in red cell membrane proteins (e.g., ankyrin, spectrin) lead to spherocyte formation, which are less deformable and prone to hemolysis.
  • Clinical Features: Hemolytic anemia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and risk of gallstones (pigment stones).
  • Diagnostic Tests: Increased osmotic fragility, high MCHC, and presence of spherocytes on peripheral smear.
  • Treatment: Folate supplementation, splenectomy for severe cases, and cholecystectomy if gallstones are symptomatic.



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 638-640.

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21dt edition, Page no 778-780.

questions.text: A patient has WBC count of 4,50,000/cumm with eosinophilia and Basophilia. Neutrophil count showed a left shift. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings strongly suggest Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML):

  1. WBC count of 4,50,000/cumm: This significantly elevated WBC count is a hallmark feature of CML.
  2. Eosinophilia and Basophilia: CML often shows an increase in eosinophils and basophils, which is less common in other leukemias.
  3. Neutrophil left shift: Indicates the presence of immature neutrophils (e.g., myelocytes, promyelocytes) in peripheral blood, a characteristic feature of CML.

Other options:
 
  • CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia):
    • Typically presents with lymphocytosis, not marked neutrophilia, eosinophilia, or basophilia.
  • AML (Acute Myeloid Leukemia):
    • Associated with blasts in peripheral blood, not a high WBC count with left shift, eosinophilia, or basophilia.
  • ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia):
    • Involves lymphoblasts and typically occurs in younger individuals.

Diagnosis:
 
  • Peripheral blood smear: Reveals mature granulocytes with a left shift, eosinophilia, and basophilia.
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Hypercellular marrow with myeloid hyperplasia.
  • Cytogenetics or Molecular Studies: Detection of the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)) or BCR-ABL fusion gene confirms the diagnosis.

Treatment:
 
  • First-line therapy includes tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., imatinib) targeting the BCR-ABL fusion protein.


 
Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 588, 594, 596, 597. 618, 619.

questions.text: HIV positive patient with diarrhea, stool examination, acid fast stain shows 4-6 micron size oocyst, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The described clinical picture of diarrhoea in an HIV patient is suggestive of an infestation with the coccidian parasite.
  • Cryptosporidium produces round oocysts of 6 um (4-6micrometer) in size and they are acid fast positive
  • Cyclospora produces oocysts of 8-10micro meter size and they are round in shape which are acid fast
  • Cysto-isospora produces oocysts which have oval in shape and are acid fast stained





Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 99-105.

questions.text: Match the following stains with their respective uses.
questions.solution:
(a) ZN stain is used to detect the presence of acid-fast bacteria such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which causes tuberculosis.
(b) Gram stain is used to differentiate bacterial species into two groups based on the differences in the cell wall structure. Gram-positive bacteria turn purple or blue, while Gram-negative bacteria turn red or pink. Therefore, option (ii) is correct.
(c) Albert stain is used to detect Corynebacterium diphtheriae
(d) Fite-Faraco stain is used to detect the presence of lipid-containing organisms such as Mycobacterium leprae.




Reference:  Chen, Ping et al. “A highly efficient Ziehl-Neelsen stain: identifying de novo intracellular Mycobacterium tuberculosis and improving detection of extracellular M. tuberculosis in cerebrospinal fluid.” Journal of clinical microbiology vol. 50,4 (2012): 1166-70. doi:10.1128/JCM.05756-11. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3318527/

Reja, Abu Hena Hasanoor et al. “Fite-Faraco staining in combination with multiplex polymerase chain reaction: a new approach to leprosy diagnosis.” Indian journal of dermatology, venereology and leprology vol. 79,5 (2013): 693-700. doi:10.4103/0378-6323.116740. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23974586/

questions.solution:

Other options:
 
  • Streptococcus - Causes Impetigo (a subcutaneous skin infection)
  • Sporotrichosis - Also known as rose gardener's disease - caused by Sporothrix is a type of subcutaneous mycosis. 
  • Nocardia - Cause of subcutaneous nocardiosis.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 204, 369, 400, 401.

questions.text:
Which of the following viruses exhibits genetic re-assortments similar to that of influzena virus? 
1. 
2. 
3. 
4.
questions.solution:
• 1- Rotavirus
  • 2- Ebola virus
  • 3- Adenovirus
  • 4- Rabies virus

Rota virus is the virus that exhibits the genetic reassortment similar to that of an influenza virus.

The rotavirus genome is a segmented, double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) genome, belonging to the family Reoviridae.
 

  • Segmented Genome:

    • Facilitates reassortment during co-infection with different rotavirus strains, contributing to genetic diversity.

  • Triple-Layered Capsid:

    • Protects the dsRNA genome from host immune responses and facilitates efficient replication and transmission.

  • Replication Factories (Viroplasms):

    • Host cell cytoplasmic structures where replication and assembly occur, avoiding detection by host defenses.

  • Cap-Independent Translation:

    • NSP3 competes with host translation factors, redirecting ribosomes to synthesize viral proteins.


Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th edition, Page no 400, 401.

questions.text: Morulae within neutrophils on peripheral smear is seen in infection with?
questions.solution:
• Morulae (microcolonies of Anaplasma) are cytoplasmic inclusions found in granulocytes of mammals infected by Anaplasma phagocytophilum.
 
  • Such morulae are seen in monocytes in Ehrlichiosis.




Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th edition, Page no 359, 361, 362.

questions.text: Molluscum contagiosum is characterized by?
questions.solution:
Henderson-Patterson bodies are characteristic to Molluscum contagiosum.
 
  • Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by the Molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV), a poxvirus.
 
  • It is characterized histologically by the presence of Henderson-Patterson bodies, which are large, eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusion bodies within the keratinocytes of the epidermis.
 
  • These inclusion bodies contain viral particles and are a hallmark of this infection.

Other options:
 
  1. Donovan bodies: Seen in Klebsiella granulomatis infections (granuloma inguinale).
  2. Halberstadter-Pravazek bodies: Found in Chlamydia trachomatis infections (trachoma or inclusion conjunctivitis).
  3. Negri bodies: Found in Rabies virus infections, located in the cytoplasm of neurons.



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 367, 733, 964, 1168.

questions.text: Affinity maturation is due to?
questions.solution:
Affinity maturation is due to somatic hypermutation.
Somatic hypermutation (SHM) of immunoglobulin (Ig) genes plays a key role in antibody mediated immunity
 
  • Affinity maturation is the process by which B cells produce antibodies with increasing affinity for their specific antigen during an immune response.
  • This occurs due to somatic hypermutation, a process where point mutations are introduced into the variable (V) regions of immunoglobulin (Ig) genes in activated B cells within the germinal centers of lymphoid tissues.
  • B cells with higher-affinity receptors are selected for survival and proliferation through interaction with antigen-presenting cells and follicular helper T cells.


Other options: 
 

  1. Isotype Switching:

    • Also called class switch recombination (CSR), it involves changing the antibody's constant region (e.g., IgM to IgG) but does not directly improve antigen-binding affinity.

  2. mRNA Splicing:

    • This is a post-transcriptional process involved in the generation of mature mRNA and is unrelated to affinity maturation.

  3. VDJ Rearrangement:

    • This occurs during B cell development in the bone marrow and generates the initial antigen-binding diversity, but it is not responsible for the improved affinity seen during the immune response.



Reference: Lange Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, 13th edition, Page no 433.

questions.text: The oncogenes  of HPV are:
questions.solution:
The oncogenic HPVs encode accessory proteins: E4, E5, E6 and E7.
These proteins modulate the cellular environment to make it more conducive for viral replication, and are important for immune evasion.
 
  • The main oncogenes of Human Papillomavirus (HPV) are E6 and E7, which play a critical role in the pathogenesis of HPV-associated cancers, particularly cervical cancer.
 
  • These proteins disrupt key tumor suppressor pathways in the host:
    • E6: Binds to and promotes the degradation of p53, a tumor suppressor protein involved in cell cycle regulation and apoptosis.
    • E7: Binds to and inactivates pRb (retinoblastoma protein), leading to uncontrolled cell cycle progression.



Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th edition, Page no 647-650.

questions.text: Receptor for EBV ?
questions.solution:
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) initiates infection of normal B lymphocytes by binding to CD21/CR2, a complement receptor.

Pathogenesis of EBV infection:
 

  1. Entry and Initial Infection:

    • EBV infects humans via saliva, targeting oropharyngeal epithelial cells and B cells.
    • It binds to CD21 (CR2) on B cells and integrins on epithelial cells.

  2. Viral Replication:

    • EBV undergoes lytic replication in epithelial cells, releasing virions that infect B cells.

  3. Latent Infection:

    • Establishes latency in memory B cells, expressing latency-associated proteins like EBNA1 and LMP1.
    • Different latency programs (I, II, III) influence disease outcomes and malignancy risk.

  4. Immune Response:

    • Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) control infection, causing symptoms of infectious mononucleosis.
    • EBV evades immunity by reducing MHC expression and minimizing viral protein production.

  5. Persistent Infection:

    • EBV persists lifelong in latent form within memory B cells, with periodic reactivation.



Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th edition, Page no 486.

questions.solution:
• Hydrops fetalis is a condition in which large amounts of fluid build up in a baby's tissues and organs, causing extensive swelling (edema).
  • HIV does not cause hydrops fetalis but rest all the given options do.

Causes of Non-immune Hydrops Fetalis:





Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 361.

questions.text: A transparent organism can be studied by adjusting the contrast and its living characteristics can also be noticed by?
questions.solution:
In a phase contrast microscope phase shifts are created as light travels through interior structures with various refractive indices, and phase plates then translate these phase shifts into changes in the amplitude of the light.
 
  • Phase-contrast microscopy is specifically designed to enhance the contrast of transparent and colorless specimens, such as living cells and microorganisms.
  • It works by exploiting differences in the refractive index of the specimen and the surrounding medium to produce high-contrast images without the need for staining, which is particularly useful for observing living organisms.

Other options:
 
  1. Dark field microscopy: Enhances contrast by illuminating the specimen with oblique light, making it appear bright against a dark background, but it is less effective for detailed internal structures.
  2. Electron Microscopy: Provides very high resolution for studying ultrastructures but requires fixed, non-living samples.
  3. Compound Microscope: A standard light microscope that typically requires staining to observe transparent specimens, making it less suitable for live studies.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 10-12.

questions.text: A patient with erectile dysfunction was prescribed sildenafil. What mediator is involved in the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
• The mechanism of action of sildenafil is that it inhibits the enzyme phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5), which is responsible for the degradation of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) in the corpus cavernosum of the penis.
 
  • By inhibiting PDE5, sildenafil increases the concentration of cGMP, which leads to smooth muscle relaxation, vasodilation, and increased blood flow to the penis.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 494, 840-842.

questions.text: A patient on ART after 6 months develops hyperpigmentation of hand and foot. The drug responsible for this condition is?
questions.solution:
Pigmentation of sun exposed areas is one of the side effects of emtricitabine.
 
  • Emtricitabine, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used in antiretroviral therapy (ART), is associated with hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles, especially in individuals with darker skin tones.
 
  • This side effect is generally benign and does not require discontinuation of the drug unless cosmetically distressing.


Other options:
 

  1. Zidovudine:

    • May cause anemia, neutropenia, and myopathy but is not commonly linked to hyperpigmentation.

  2. Nevirapine:

    • A non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) associated with hypersensitivity reactions, including rash and hepatotoxicity, but not hyperpigmentation.

  3. Ritonavir:

    • A protease inhibitor, primarily associated with gastrointestinal side effects, lipid abnormalities, and fat redistribution (lipodystrophy).



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 1140, 1143, 1144, 1151.

questions.text:
Match the following 
a. Imatinib (i) Mtor inhibitor
b. Sirolimus (ii) BCR-ABL kinase
c. Trastuzumab (iii) TNF alpha inhibitor
d. Infliximab (iv) HER2 neu inhitor
questions.solution:
• a. Imatinib – (ii) BCR-ABL kinase inhibitor

    • Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor specifically targeting the BCR-ABL fusion protein found in chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).

  • b. Sirolimus – (i) mTOR inhibitor

    • Sirolimus is an immunosuppressive drug that inhibits the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR), used in preventing organ rejection in transplant patients.

  • c. Trastuzumab – (iv) HER2 neu inhibitor

    • Trastuzumab (Herceptin) is a monoclonal antibody that targets the HER2/neu receptor, used in the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer.

  • d. Infliximab – (iii) TNF-alpha inhibitor

    • Infliximab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), used in the treatment of inflammatory conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and Crohn's disease.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 775, 776, 781, 1339.

questions.text: Name the drug acting on point (5)?
questions.solution:
Point 5 shows the action of Integrase

Raltegravir and Dolutegravir acts as Integrase inhibitor.





Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 1139, 1140, 1143.

questions.text: Peripheral blood smear showing sporozoite of plasmodium falciparum in RBC. Patient has seizures. Which is the preferred treatment?
questions.solution:
Parenteral artesunate is the drug of choice for cerebral malaria and this clinical scenario is indicative of cerebral malaria.
 
  • Plasmodium falciparum is the most serious species of malaria, and its infection can lead to cerebral malaria, which is often associated with seizures.
  • The preferred treatment for severe falciparum malaria (including cerebral malaria) is IV artesunate, a fast-acting artemisinin derivative.
    • Inj. Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg is given initially, followed by additional doses as per the protocol for severe malaria.
  • Artesunate is considered more effective than quinine, especially in severe cases, due to its rapid action and better safety profile.


Other options:
 

  1. Tab. Chloroquine:

    • Not effective against Plasmodium falciparum in regions with resistance. It is typically used for non-severe, sensitive malaria caused by other Plasmodium species.

  2. Tab. Doxycycline:

    • Doxycycline is used for prophylaxis and treatment of uncomplicated malaria, particularly for Plasmodium vivax, but not recommended in severe cases of falciparum malaria.

  3. Tab. Quinine:

    • Quinine is another treatment for severe malaria but is less preferred than artesunate for severe falciparum malaria, especially with cerebral involvement.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1730-1733.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the shown graph?
questions.solution:
The graph shown is a Dose-response curve, which is used to determine the relationship between the dose or concentration of a drug and its effect. In this case, the graph shows the response of a tissue to three different drugs A,B & C.
  • The correct option is 3 as both Drug A & B are producing the same effect.
  • The y-axis represents the response of the drug, and the x-axis represents the concentration of the drug.
  • In this graph, both A and B are producing a response in the tissue, which means they are agonists.
  • Potency refers to the concentration of the drug required to produce a certain response. In this graph, we can see that drug A is more potent than drug B because a lower concentration of drug A is required to produce the same response as a higher concentration of drug B.
  • Efficacy refers to the maximum response that can be produced by a drug. In this graph, we can see that drug A is equally efficacious to drug B because it produces an equal maximum response at the highest concentration.
  • Whereas, Both A & B are more efficacious and more potent than Drug C. 
  • Drug C is a partial agonist.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 45-47.

questions.text: New drug application is done after which phase of clinical trial?
questions.solution:
After the Phase III trial, the FDA reviews the clinical trial results to make sure the treatment is safe and effective for people to use.
 
  • A New Drug Application (NDA) is submitted to regulatory authorities (e.g., the FDA) after the completion of Phase 3 clinical trials.
    • Phase 3 trials involve large-scale testing to confirm the drug's effectiveness, monitor side effects, and compare it to standard treatments or placebos.
    • If the results are positive and meet the required safety and efficacy standards, the NDA is filed for regulatory review and approval for general use.

Other options:
 
  1. Phase 1:
    • Focuses on safety and dosage in a small group of healthy volunteers.
  2. Phase 2:
    • Focuses on efficacy and safety in a larger group of patients with the disease being treated.
  3. Phase 4:
    • Occurs after the drug has been approved and marketed. It monitors long-term effects and collects additional data on the drug’s safety and efficacy.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 6, 7.

questions.text: In a clinical trial 400-500 patients were taken to find the efficacy of a new drug in multiple centers, half were given a new drug, and half were given a placebo, both patients and researchers were blinded, this is done in which phase of the clinical trail?
questions.solution:
• The given scenario describes a randomized controlled trial (RCT) where a new drug is tested against a placebo in multiple centers with blinding of both patients and researchers to test and confirm its efficacy.
  • This type of trial is typically conducted in Phase 3 of clinical trials.
 
  • Phase 3 trials are designed to confirm the efficacy and safety of a new drug in a larger population (typically 400-500 patients or more) and across multiple centers.
  • Randomized controlled trials (RCTs), where participants are randomly assigned to either the new drug or a placebo, are commonly used in Phase 3.
  • Blinding (both patients and researchers being unaware of the treatment group) is a typical feature of Phase 3 trials to prevent bias in the results.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 14.

questions.text:
Which of the following act on agonist on beta-2 receptor? 
(i) Dipivefrine 
(ii) Fenoldopam 
(iii) Mirabegron 
(iv) Dopexamine
questions.solution:
1. Dipivefrine:

    • Prodrug of epinephrine. Epinephrine activates beta-2 receptors, so dipivefrine indirectly acts as a beta-2 agonist.

  2. Fenoldopam:

    • Selective dopamine D1 receptor agonist with no significant beta-2 receptor activity. It does not act on beta-2 receptors.

  3. Mirabegron:

    • Selective beta-3 adrenergic receptor agonist used for overactive bladder. It does not significantly affect beta-2 receptors.

  4. Dopexamine:

    • Dopamine agonist with beta-2 receptor agonist activity. It stimulates beta-2 receptors and is used to enhance cardiac output.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 259, 261, 262.

questions.text: Most effective drug for smoking cessation?
questions.solution:
Varenicline blocks the ability of nicotine to activate its receptors on the brain.
  • It is the most effective drug in smoking cessation.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 185-188, 437.

questions.text: In middle aged diabetic patient with CKD-stage 5, which of the following drugs can be safely given?
questions.solution:

  • Because it is eliminated by hepatobiliary route therefore no dose adjustment is needed in case of renal failure.


Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 1034, 1038, 1039.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with lymphatic filariasis is taken care as shown in the image, It indicates which level of prevention?
questions.solution:
The image illustrates a confirmed case of chronic lymphatic filariasis, where hygiene practices are being upheld to prevent additional disability caused by secondary bacterial infections. Limiting disability is an intervention strategy within tertiary prevention.


Other options:

  • Option 1: Primary prevention refers to actions taken before the onset of a disease to eliminate the possibility of its occurrence. This involves measures to promote overall health and well-being.
 
  • Option 2: Specific protection is an intervention within primary prevention aimed at reducing the occurrence of a particular disease. This includes measures like immunization, use of specific nutrients, chemoprophylaxis, accident prevention, and allergen avoidance.
 
  • Option 3: Health promotion, a primary prevention strategy, involves empowering individuals to enhance control over and improve their health. It can be achieved through health education, environmental modifications, nutritional interventions, or lifestyle changes.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 42, 49, 297, 298.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, hand sanitizer cannot be used?
questions.solution:
• If hands are visibly soiled then washing with soap and water for at least 60 seconds is recommended.
  • Hand sanitizers are effective in reducing microbial load on hands in most situations, but they are not effective when hands are visibly soiled or contaminated with organic matter (e.g., dirt, blood, or bodily fluids).
  • In such cases, washing hands with soap and water is necessary.

Other options:
 
  1. Before examining a patient: Hand sanitizer can be used to disinfect hands.
  2. After examining a patient: Hand sanitizer is appropriate to reduce potential contamination.
  3. After touching the patient's surroundings: Hand sanitizer can be used effectively in this situation as well.



Reference: Hand sanitizer Guidelines and Recommendations, CDC guidelines. URL: https://www.cdc.gov/clean-hands/about/hand-sanitizer.html#:~:text=Don't%20use%20hand%20sanitizer,with%20soap%20and%20water%20instead.

questions.text:
Dog bite with bleeding from affected bite. What are the correct statements? 
(i) Inject vaccines -0, 3,7,14, 28 days 
(ii) Clean with soap for 10 mins 
(iii) Single dose of equine rabies IG given 40 IU/kg 
(iv) Suture the wound 
(v) Category 3 wound
questions.solution:
1. (i) Inject vaccines - 0, 3, 7, 14, 28 days
    Correct. For Category 3 bites (high-risk, bleeding wounds), the rabies post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) schedule involves vaccinations on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28. (IM regime)

  2. (ii) Clean with soap for 10 minutes
    Correct. Washing the wound thoroughly with soap and water for 10-15 minutes is critical for reducing viral contamination and the risk of rabies transmission.

  3. (iii) Single dose of equine rabies IG given 40 IU/kg
    Correct. For Category 3 wounds, a single dose of equine rabies immunoglobulin (ERIG) at 40 IU/kg is administered, primarily infiltrating the wound site with the remaining dose given intramuscularly.

  4. (iv) Suture the wound
    Incorrect. Suturing is typically not recommended for rabies-prone wounds as it may trap the virus. If necessary, delayed suturing is performed after wound treatment and RIG administration.

  5. (v) Category 3 wound
    Correct. A dog bite that results in bleeding is classified as a Category 3 wound, requiring immediate PEP (vaccination and immunoglobulin).


     

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 324-326.

questions.text: HOOCH tragedy is due to?
questions.solution:

questions.text: This Kit is used for treatment of which disease?
questions.solution:
This is a kit used for treatment of malaria.

  • Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine (SP): A slow-acting partner drug that eliminates residual parasites and prevents resistance development.

Indications:
 
  • Primarily used in areas with Plasmodium falciparum malaria where resistance to other therapies is common.
  • Often employed in regions where SP retains efficacy.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 308-310.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
In phase III of clinical trials, 500-3000 patients (not 5-10) are taken.
 

  1. Phase 1 - Pharmacokinetics:
    Correct. Phase 1 trials focus on understanding the pharmacokinetics (absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion) and pharmacodynamics (effect on the body) of a drug, as well as its safety profile. These trials typically involve a small number of healthy volunteers (20-100).

  2. Phase 4 - Post-marketing surveillance:
    Correct. Phase 4 involves monitoring the drug's safety and effectiveness in the general population after it has been approved for marketing. This is known as post-marketing surveillance.

  3. Phase 3 - 5-10 patients are taken:
    Incorrect. Phase 3 trials are large-scale studies involving hundreds to thousands of patients (usually 300-3,000 or more). These trials aim to confirm the drug's efficacy, monitor side effects, and compare it to standard treatments.

  4. Phase 0 - Microdosing:
    Correct. Phase 0 involves administering sub-therapeutic doses (microdosing) to a very small number of participants to gather preliminary data on how the drug behaves in the human body.




Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 6, 7.

choices.text: Annual new case detection rate (ANCDR) per 100000 population
Proportion of grade II disabilities among new cases

questions.text: Which of the following is a quality service indicator under NLEP?
questions.solution:
Under the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP), quality service indicators focus on the effectiveness of early diagnosis, treatment quality, and prevention of disabilities. The proportion of grade II disabilities among new cases indicates the efficiency of early detection efforts in preventing severe disabilities caused by leprosy.


Other indicators:
 

  1. Annual New Case Detection Rate (ANCDR) per 100,000 population:
    This measures the burden of leprosy but is more of an epidemiological indicator than a quality service indicator.

  2. Proportion of multi-bacillary among new cases:
    This tracks the proportion of severe forms of leprosy but is not a direct quality service indicator.

  3. Proportion of treatment defaulters:
    This is a measure of adherence and service coverage but not primarily a quality service indicator.

  4. Proportion of grade II disabilities among new cases (Correct):
    A higher proportion reflects delayed diagnosis, while a lower proportion indicates better service quality in identifying cases early, making it a key quality service indicator under NLEP.




Reference:  Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page no 372.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A fisherman with a history of trauma with a fish tail presents with pain and blurring of vision. What is the sign in the picture?
questions.solution:
• Hypopyon is the accumulation of neutrophils and fibrin that typically settles ventrally within the anterior chamber.
 
  • The white pus settled in the anterior chamber as shown in the image is the hypopyon. 


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 105, 110, 160, 521.

questions.text: A patient with vision of 6/6, standing at a distance of 6 meters from the snellen's chart looking at the last line, makes what angle of resolution at the nodal point of his eye?
questions.solution:
• A person with 6/6 vision can resolve details on the smallest line of the Snellen chart when standing at 6 meters.
  • Each letter on the 6/6 line is designed to subtend an angle of 5 minutes of arc (5′) at the nodal point of the eye.
  • This is the standard definition of normal visual acuity, where the angular resolution of the eye is 1 minute of arc (1′) between two points, and the overall size of the smallest resolvable letter subtends 5′.

Thus, the angle subtended by the smallest line of letters (the 6/6 line) at the nodal point is 5 minutes of arc.




Reference: Parson's Diseases pf the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 84-89.

questions.text: Use of atropine is contraindicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Atropine, a muscarinic receptor antagonist, causes pupillary dilation (mydriasis) and paralysis of the ciliary muscle (cycloplegia).**

  1. Angle-closure glaucoma:

    • Atropine is contraindicated because pupillary dilation can worsen the angle closure, leading to increased intraocular pressure (IOP). This can exacerbate optic nerve damage and cause acute symptoms like pain, nausea, and vision loss.

  2. Malignant glaucoma:

    • Atropine is generally avoided but not the primary contraindication. Other medications are more relevant to malignant glaucoma.

  3. Corneal ulcer:

    • While atropine is not specifically contraindicated, it may sometimes be used to provide relief from ciliary spasm.

  4. Anterior uveitis:

    • Atropine is commonly used to reduce pain from ciliary spasm, prevent synechiae (adhesions), and keep the pupil mobile.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 108, 164, 247.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs act via the trabecular outflow pathway?
questions.solution:
The trabecular outflow pathway refers to the drainage of aqueous humor through the trabecular meshwork and into Schlemm’s canal. Drugs that increase trabecular outflow reduce intraocular pressure (IOP) by enhancing the drainage through this pathway. 

  1. Netarsudil:

    • A Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitor and norepinephrine transporter inhibitor.
    • It improves trabecular outflow by relaxing the trabecular meshwork and reducing resistance to aqueous humor outflow.
    • This is its primary mechanism of action.

  2. Timolol:

    • A beta-blocker that reduces aqueous humor production by the ciliary body.
    • It does not act directly on the trabecular outflow pathway.

  3. Brimonidine:

    • An alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that reduces aqueous humor production and increases uveoscleral outflow.
    • It does not enhance trabecular outflow.

  4. Bimatoprost:

    • A prostaglandin analog that primarily increases uveoscleral outflow, with a minor effect on trabecular outflow in some cases.
    • Its primary mechanism is not trabecular outflow.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 243.

questions.text: Identify the condition given below in the image?
questions.solution:
• Ankyloblepharon is defined by partial or complete adhesion of the ciliary edges of superior and inferior eyelids.
  • It is usually a sporadic isolated malformation in which the upper and lower lids are joined by tags.

Other options:

  1. Symblepharon: (Option 1)

    • Refers to adhesion between the palpebral conjunctiva (inner eyelid) and the bulbar conjunctiva (eye surface).
    • Commonly caused by trauma, burns, or cicatricial diseases like Stevens-Johnson syndrome.
    • It does not involve fusion of the eyelids themselves.

  2. Blepharophimosis: (Option 3)

    • A congenital condition characterized by narrowing of the palpebral fissure (horizontal eyelid opening).
    • It does not involve eyelid fusion.

  3. Epiblepharon: (Option 4)

    • A congenital abnormality where an extra fold of skin near the eyelid margin pushes the lashes inward.
    • This condition does not involve eyelid fusion.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 393, 395.

questions.solution:
• Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19.
  • It is typically mild and presents with symptoms like redness, tearing, foreign body sensation, and photophobia.
  • This condition is thought to occur due to the viral infection or the associated inflammatory response.

URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34020483/

questions.text: What is the most common condition causing moderate-severe blindness in India?
questions.solution:
In India, cataract is the most common cause of moderate to severe blindness. Here's a breakdown of the listed conditions:

  1. Cataract:

    • Accounts for the majority of blindness cases in India, particularly in older adults.
    • This is due to delayed access to surgical intervention, lack of awareness, and inadequate healthcare resources in rural areas.
    • Cataract blindness is treatable, and surgery is highly effective in restoring vision.

  2. Glaucoma:

    • A significant cause of irreversible blindness but ranks lower in prevalence compared to cataract.
    • Often asymptomatic in the early stages, leading to late diagnosis and management.

  3. Refractive Error:

    • The leading cause of avoidable visual impairment, but it is not the most common cause of moderate-severe blindness.
    • Proper correction with glasses or contact lenses can address this issue.

  4. Diabetic Retinopathy:

    • Increasing in prevalence due to the rising incidence of diabetes in India.
    • However, it is not as common as cataract when considering blindness on a population scale.



Reference: National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey India 2015-2019- A summary report, NPCBVI, MoHFW, GoI. URL: npcbvi.mohfw,gov.in/writeReadData/mainlinkFile/File341.pdf

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in complicated cataract?
questions.solution:
• Complicated cataract is a cataract that develops secondary to another ocular pathology, such as uveitis, glaucoma, or retinal detachment. It typically shows:

    • Bread crumb appearance: A granular or mottled appearance of the lens cortex.
    • Polychromatic lustre: Multicolored shimmering appearance due to changes in the lens proteins.
    • Appear after uveitis: Complicated cataracts commonly develop after chronic inflammation, such as uveitis.
 

  • Krukenberg spindle, on the other hand, is a vertical spindle-shaped deposit of pigmented cells on the corneal endothelium. It is a sign of pigment dispersion syndrome or pigmentary glaucoma, not associated with complicated cataracts.




Reference: Parson's Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 239, 276.

choices.text: CT scan is the investigation of choice

questions.text: Which of the following is true about optic neuritis?
questions.solution:
RAPD (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect) or Marcus gun pupil phenomenon is seen in case of optic neuritis.
 
  • Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD):
    • This is a hallmark feature of optic neuritis. It indicates an asymmetry in the afferent visual pathway and is detected using the swinging flashlight test.

Other options:
 

  1. Most common cause is Multiple Myeloma:

    • Incorrect. The most common cause of optic neuritis is multiple sclerosis (MS), not multiple myeloma. It may also occur due to infections or autoimmune conditions.

  2. Oral steroids are treatment of choice:

    • Incorrect. Oral steroids alone are not the treatment of choice because they have been shown to increase the recurrence rate of optic neuritis. High-dose IV methylprednisolone is preferred for faster recovery of vision, though the overall visual prognosis is good even without treatment.

  3. CT scan is the investigation of choice:

    • Incorrect. The investigation of choice is MRI of the brain and orbits with contrast, as it is sensitive in detecting demyelinating lesions and optic nerve inflammation. CT scans are less sensitive for such changes.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 329-331.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in keratoconus?
questions.solution:
Habb's striae are horizontal breaks in descement's membrane seen in congenital glaucoma.
 

  • Keratoconus is a progressive, non-inflammatory thinning of the cornea leading to its conical protrusion. Key features include:

    1. Irregular astigmatism: Caused by distortion of the corneal surface.
    2. Munson's sign: A V-shaped indentation of the lower eyelid seen in downgaze, due to the conical shape of the cornea.
    3. Scissoring reflex on retinoscopy: A characteristic finding due to irregular corneal curvature.
 

  • Haab's striae, on the other hand, are horizontal breaks in Descemet's membrane seen in congenital glaucoma, not keratoconus.




Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 100, 135-137.

choices.text: Simple excision can result in 90-95% reduction in recurrence

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the given condition?
questions.solution:
The image shown is of pterygium and it's surgical excision has high rate of recurrence therefore third statement is incorrect. Simple excision alone is associated with a high recurrence rate (up to 30-50% or more). To significantly reduce recurrence (to 5-10%), adjunctive therapies such as: Conjunctival autografting, Mitomycin C, or Amniotic membrane grafting are often required. 

Other options

Option 1 - This is a true statement. Pterygium is fibrovascular overgrowth of the subconjunctival tissue

Option 2 - Pterygium has a distinct anatomy: Head: The apex extending toward the cornea; Neck: The middle part. and Body: The broader conjunctival part. Hence, option 2 is also correc

Option 4 - Correct.  Pterygium is classified as:
  • Progressive: Actively growing, vascular, and can encroach on the visual axis.
  • Regressive: Quiescent, less vascular, and non-threatening.
Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 90; Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 198, 199.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common tumor to be associated with retinoblastoma?
questions.solution:
• RB1 gene present on chromosome 13 is a tumor suppressor gene that is mutated in patients with Retinoblastoma.
 
  • Amongst other common tumors caused due to RB gene mutations - Osteosarcoma is the most common tumor followed by STS (Soft tissue sarcoma). 

  • Retinoblastoma is associated with a germline mutation in the RB1 tumor suppressor gene. This mutation increases the risk of developing other malignancies, particularly in hereditary retinoblastoma cases.

  • Osteosarcoma:

    • It is the most common second primary tumor in survivors of hereditary retinoblastoma, typically arising in adolescence or adulthood.
    • The risk is particularly elevated due to the same RB1 mutation involved in cell cycle regulation.


Other options:
 

  1. Medulloblastoma:

    • While it is a common brain tumor in children, it is not significantly associated with retinoblastoma.

  2. Melanoma:

    • There is a slightly increased risk of melanoma in hereditary retinoblastoma survivors, but it is less common than osteosarcoma.

  3. Pinealoblastoma:

    • Also called trilateral retinoblastoma when associated with bilateral retinoblastoma.
    • It is a rare association seen in hereditary cases but is much less common than osteosarcoma.



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 2698.

questions.text:
Match the following:
1. Goldmann's applanation tonometer (a) Visual field
2. Ishihara chart (b) IOP
3. Perimeter (c) Central vision
4. Pinhole (d) Color vision
questions.solution:
1. Goldmann's applanation tonometer → (b) IOP:

    • This device is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP), which is crucial for diagnosing glaucoma.

  2. Ishihara chart → (d) Color vision:

    • The Ishihara chart is used to test for color vision deficiencies, particularly red-green color blindness.

  3. Perimeter → (a) Visual field:

    • Perimetry measures the visual field, assessing peripheral and central vision, commonly used in glaucoma.

  4. Pinhole → (c) Central vision:

    • The pinhole test helps evaluate central vision by reducing refractive errors, isolating issues like uncorrected refractive errors from organic eye disease.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 343, 531, 533.

questions.text:
Match the following 
a. Type II Tympanoplasty 1. Graft on round window
b. Type III Tympanoplasty 2. Fenestration operation
c. Type IV Tympanoplasty 3. Graft in Incus
d. Type V Tympanoplasty 4. Graft on Head of stapes
questions.solution:
• Type II Tympanoplasty → 3. Graft in Incus:

    • The ossicular chain is partially disrupted, so the graft is placed on the incus to restore continuity.

  • Type III Tympanoplasty → 4. Graft on Head of Stapes:

    • In this procedure, the graft is placed directly on the head of the stapes when the malleus and incus are absent.

  • Type IV Tympanoplasty → 1. Graft on Round Window:

    • The ossicular chain is absent, and the graft covers the round window to protect the inner ear while allowing sound conduction.

  • Type V Tympanoplasty → 2. Fenestration operation:

    • Used in cases of fixed stapes footplate or severe ossicular damage; a new opening (fenestration) is created to improve hearing.


TYPES OF TYMPANOPLASTY:
