questions.text: Foreign entry in laryngeal inlet is prevented by cough reflex. Reflex is sluggish in alcohol ingestion and some other conditions. Which nerve is likely injured damaged?
questions.solution:
• Here is the physiology behind cough:
  • When triggered, impulses travel via the internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve which stems from the vagus nerve (CN X) to the medulla of the brain. This is the afferent neural pathway.
 
  • The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (ILN) is responsible for sensory innervation to the mucosa of the laryngeal inlet, epiglottis, and the upper part of the vocal cords. It detects foreign entry and triggers the cough reflex.
  • If this nerve is damaged or its function is impaired (e.g., by alcohol ingestion or other conditions), the reflex becomes sluggish, leading to an increased risk of aspiration.



Other options:
 

  1. ELN (External branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve): Provides motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle and does not play a sensory role in the laryngeal inlet.
  2. RLN (Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve): Supplies motor innervation to most intrinsic laryngeal muscles and sensory innervation below the vocal cords, but it’s not directly involved in detecting foreign entry at the laryngeal inlet.
  3. Glossopharyngeal Nerve (CN IX): Supplies sensation to the oropharynx and is involved in the gag reflex but not the cough reflex at the laryngeal inlet.



Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 8th edition, Page no 335, 347-351.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cardiac poison?
questions.solution:
Atropine is derived from Atropa Belladona which is a Deliriant.
Examples of cardiac poisons—
  • Digitalis
  • Oleander
  • Nicotine
  • Aconite.
 
  1. Aconite - A highly toxic plant that acts as a cardiac poison by altering the sodium channels, leading to arrhythmias.
  2. Atropa Belladonna - While it contains alkaloids like atropine that affect the autonomic nervous system (causing anticholinergic symptoms like tachycardia), it is not classified as a direct cardiac poison.
  3. Cerebra Thevetia - Known as the "Yellow Oleander," it contains cardiac glycosides that can cause severe cardiotoxicity, including arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
  4. Digitalis purpurea - Contains cardiac glycosides (e.g., digoxin), which are classic cardiac poisons that can lead to arrhythmias at toxic doses.



Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 598-600.

questions.text: Identify the type of death?
questions.solution:
• Garrotting is a type of asphyxia in which throat may be grasped, or a ligature is thrown over the neck and quickly tightened, by twisting it with a lever, within the ligature, which results in sudden loss of consciousness and collapse. 
 
  • Garrotting as a mode of judicial execution was once employed in Spain.
 
  • An iron collar around the neck was tightened by a screw for strangling (Spanish Windlass).



Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 350, 359, 360.

questions.solution:

  • Datura is a genus of flowering plants that are poisonous and contain several alkaloids, including scopolamine and hyoscyamine.
  • Roti seed is a common name for the seeds of Abrus precatorius, which contain the toxic protein abrin.

questions.text: In a gunshot case, tattooing is noted surrounding a firearm entry wound. Tattooing occurs mainly due to ?
questions.solution:
Tattooing in gunshot wounds is mainly seen due to unburnt particles.
 
  • 'Tattooing' is pathognomonic for an intermediate range gunshot wound.
 
  • Tattooing is a term used to describe the punctate abrasions observed when epithelial tissue comes into contact with partially burned or unburned grains of gunpowder.



Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 215-217, 221-224.

questions.text: Dead body of a child was recovered from a river with froth over the mouth which comes back even after wiping. Which of the following post-mortem findings will not be seen?
questions.solution:
Arsenic in hair is not related to the case.

Other features are seen in a case of drowning:
  • Cadaveric spasm is the surest sign of antemortem drowning.
  • Paltauf’s hemorrhages are patches of hemorrhages on the anterior aspect and margins of the lungs subpleurally. These are caused due to rupture of alveoli during forceful expiration, thus indicating great struggle as in drowning.

 



Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 368, 369.

questions.text: Patient with h/o previous surgery comes to hospital with abdominal pain and fever. X-ray abdomen shows the following finding. This corresponds to:
questions.solution:
• Res ipsa loquitur is latin for "the thing speaks for itself."
  • It is sufficient to prove the negligence of any doctor.
  • E.g. Wrong dose in prescription cards, presence of swab/ instrument in patient's body following surgery.
  • It can be proof of civil and criminal negligence.

Res ipsa loquitur is a Latin term meaning "the thing speaks for itself." It is a legal doctrine used in cases where the negligence is so obvious that it requires no further proof. In this scenario, the presence of scissors left in the abdomen after surgery is clear evidence of negligence, fitting the concept of Res ipsa loquitur.


Other options:
 

  1. Res Judicata - A legal principle meaning "a matter already judged." It prevents the same case from being tried again once it has been resolved.
  2. Novus actus interveniens - A new, independent act that breaks the chain of causation in a legal case. This is not applicable here.
  3. Vicarious liability - Legal responsibility of a superior (e.g., hospital) for the acts of their subordinates (e.g., a surgeon). While the hospital may be liable, this concept does not directly apply to the scenario described.




Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 38, 39, 45-47.

  • It is also known as bruise.

questions.text: Alkalinization of urine leads to increased excretion of?
questions.solution:
Weakly acidic drugs (pH 5-8) ionize more & are thus reabsorbed less in alkaline medium leading to their increased excretion. E.g- Barbiturates, sulfonamides, chlorpropamide and NSAIDs.
 
  • Urine alkalinization increases the excretion of weak acidic drugs by enhancing their ionization.
  • When urine pH is increased (made more alkaline), weak acids lose a proton, becoming ionized. Ionized drugs are less lipophilic and cannot easily diffuse back across the renal tubule, so they are excreted more readily.

Examples of weak acidic drugs:
  • Salicylates (e.g., aspirin)
  • Barbiturates
  • Methotrexate
  • Phenobarbital



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 63.

questions.text: A Scorpion Sting case comes to casualty with features of pain, hypotension and pulmonary edema. Antidote of choice in such case is
questions.solution:
• Antidote of choice for scorpion sting is scorpion anti venom but Prazosin is given initially.
  • Prazosin, a postsynaptic alpha-1 blocker, counteracts the effects of excessive catecholamines and arrests the development of severe systemic features.
  • Scorpion antivenom directly neutralizes the venom, addressing the root cause of systemic symptoms like pain, hypotension, and pulmonary edema caused by the scorpion sting.
  • It is the definitive treatment when available, as it halts the progression of envenomation.

Other options:
 
  • Prazosin (1): A supportive treatment that counteracts the effects of excessive catecholamines (such as vasoconstriction and pulmonary edema), but it is not a direct antidote.
  • Furosemide (2): A diuretic, generally avoided in scorpion envenomation as it can exacerbate hypovolemia and worsen hypotension.
  • Dopamine (4): May be used to support blood pressure in cases of severe hypotension, but it does not counteract the venom's effects and is not the antidote.

In severe systemic scorpion envenomation, Scorpion antivenom is the antidote of choice, with prazosin playing a key supportive role in symptomatic management.




Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 566.

questions.text:
Which of the following are associated with MEN-2A syndrome? 
(i) Parathyroid hyperplasia 
(ii) Medullary ca-thyroid
(iii) Cafe-au-lait-spots
(iv) Optic nerve glioma
questions.solution:
• MEN 2A syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the endocrine glands and causes a type of thyroid cancer called medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid gland cancer.
  • It may also cause benign (noncancerous) tumors in the parathyroid glands and adrenal glands.

Other options:
 
  • Cafe-au-lait spots (iii): These are associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), not MEN-2A.
  • Optic nerve glioma (iv): Also a feature of NF1, not MEN-2A.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2984.

questions.text: Earliest sign/symptom of GB carcinoma?
questions.solution:
• Patients may be asymptomatic at the time of diagnosis.
  • Symptoms, if present, are usually undistinguished from those of Benign GB disease such as biliary colic or cholecystitis, particularly in older patients.
  • Jaundice & anemia are late features and a palpable mass is a very late sign.


The earliest symptom is typically colicky pain (biliary colic), usually in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. This pain may result from intermittent obstruction of the bile duct or inflammation associated with gallbladder stones, a common coexisting condition.


Other options:
 
  1. Jaundice:
    • Occurs later in the disease due to biliary obstruction from tumor growth or metastasis.
  2. Palpable mass:
    • A palpable mass indicates significant tumor growth or advanced disease.
  3. Ascites:
    • A late manifestation, often due to peritoneal spread or advanced-stage disease.

Significance:
 

Early diagnosis of gallbladder carcinoma is challenging because of its vague symptoms. Patients with risk factors (e.g., gallstones, porcelain gallbladder, or chronic cholecystitis) presenting with persistent or unusual colicky pain should be evaluated for GBC.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1258.

questions.text:
Patient is referred with necrotizing acute pancreatitis with collection on CECT. Abdomen patient is on vasopressor with BP=90/60 mmHg. What are the initial things you will do? 
(a) Laparotomy and Necrosectomy 
(b) MRI to visualize the pancreatic ducts 
(c) Percutaneous aspiration of fluid under image guidance 
(d) IV antibiotics
questions.solution:
• Step up approach is used in management of infected necrosis.
  • Percutaneous drainage is done under the guidance of pigtail catheter along with minimally invasive retroperitoneal debridement.
  • Open necrosectomy has high mortality rate. Once infection has been demonstrated, IV antibiotics should be given.
  • Because of their penetration into the pancreas and spectrum coverage, carbapenems are the first option of treatment.
 

  • (c) Percutaneous aspiration of fluid under image guidance:

    • This is performed to confirm infection in the pancreatic or peripancreatic collection by obtaining fluid for culture and sensitivity.
    • It is a minimally invasive approach suitable for critically ill patients.
 

  • (d) IV antibiotics:

    • If infection is confirmed or highly suspected, empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated to control sepsis. Common choices include carbapenems (e.g., meropenem) for their coverage against gram-negative bacteria and anaerobes.



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1538-1540.

choices.text: Most of the cases of CA-stomach are hereditary
Intestinal variety is caused by CDH1 gene mutation
Depth of invasion has no prognostic value

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement related to CA-stomach?
questions.solution:
1. Hereditary cases (Option 1):

    • Most cases of gastric carcinoma are sporadic, not hereditary. However, hereditary diffuse gastric cancer (HDGC) is a subtype associated with CDH1 gene mutations.
    • Sporadic gastric cancers are often linked to environmental factors like H. pylori infection, diet, and smoking.

  2. E-Cadherin loss (Option 2):

    • The diffuse variety of gastric cancer is associated with the loss of E-Cadherin, a protein encoded by the CDH1 gene. This leads to loss of cell adhesion and increased invasiveness.
    • Diffuse gastric cancer typically presents as poorly cohesive cells, often signet-ring cells, and is not associated with gland formation.

  3. Intestinal variety and CDH1 mutation (Option 3):

    • The intestinal type of gastric cancer is associated with chronic H. pylori infection, atrophic gastritis, and intestinal metaplasia, not primarily CDH1 mutations.

  4. Depth of invasion and prognosis (Option 4):

    • The depth of invasion is a critical prognostic factor in gastric cancer. Tumors that invade deeper layers (e.g., serosa) are associated with a poorer prognosis.



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1219-1222.

choices.text: Used as monotherapy-not in combination with AChE inhibitors

questions.text: True about Memantine?
questions.solution:
Memantine is a clinically useful drug in many neurological disorders, including Alzheimer's disease( mild to moderate form)
  • The principal mechanism of action of memantine is believed to be the blockade of current flow through channels of N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) glutamate receptors.
 

  • Used as monotherapy-not in combination with AChE inhibitors (Incorrect):

    • Memantine can be used as monotherapy or in combination with acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitors (e.g., donepezil) for moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease.

  • Dose is 500mg per day (Incorrect):

    • The typical dose of memantine is 10–20 mg per day, not 500 mg.

  • Given intravenously (Incorrect):

    • Memantine is administered orally, either as tablets or oral solution. It is not given intravenously.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 333, 337.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mode of spread of abdominal TB?
questions.solution:

  • Close contact with animals having TB is a mode of spread for bovine TB can be transmitted to humans through consumption of contaminated dairy products or close contact with infected animals.
 
  • Feco-oral transmission is not a mode of spread of abdominal TB.

questions.text: A 60 year old patient came with a H/O-Hyponatremia. He was treated with large volumes of hypertonic fluids over 23 hours followed by which the patient develops quadriparesis. What is the most likely cause for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This is a typical history of sudden correction of hyponatremia, leading to central pontine myelinolysis, a common complication associated with the treatment of hyponataemia.
 
  • Central pontine myelinolysis is demyelination without inflammation at the base of the pons with relative sparing of axons and nerve cells.
  • It typically presents as a devastating condition such as quadriplegia and pseudobulbar palsy.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 344, 347, 2273, 3408, 3435, 3554.

questions.solution:
Absolute Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke:
  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding tendency
  • Recent history of head injury or intracranial hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in past 2 weeks
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in past 3 weeks
  • Recent MI (within 3 months)

questions.text: Which of the following is most specific antibody for SLE?
questions.solution:

  • Specific antibody for SLE— Anti-Smith antibody
 
  • Marker for drug induced SLE—  Anti histone antibody.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2736-2746, 2751.

questions.text: A patient completed triple drug regimen for H.Pylori. Which investigation will be best to assess treatment response?
questions.solution:
For treatment follow up, Breath urease test is the most sensitive test.
 

The urea breath test (UBT) is the most reliable, non-invasive method to assess the eradication of H. pylori after treatment.

  • High Sensitivity and Specificity: UBT detects active infection by measuring urease activity, an enzyme produced by H. pylori.
  • Non-Invasive: Unlike endoscopic biopsy, it does not require an invasive procedure.
  • Timing: It is recommended 4–6 weeks after completing therapy to allow clearance of dead bacteria and to avoid false-negative results due to residual antibiotics or proton pump inhibitors (PPIs).

Other options:
 

  1. Biopsy urease test:

    • Requires endoscopy and is invasive.
    • May produce false negatives if sampling is inadequate or if the patient is on PPIs or antibiotics.

  2. Upper GI endoscopy:

    • Primarily used for diagnosing complications like ulcers or malignancy, not for treatment response monitoring.

  3. Serology:

    • Detects antibodies to H. pylori, but cannot differentiate between active and past infection.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1279-1281.

questions.text: What is the Corrected reticulocyte count, if Hb=5, reticulocyte =9% ?
questions.solution:
Corrected reticulocyte count= Reticulocyte % × (Patient Hb/Normal Hb)
Normal Hb= 15g/dl.

Here, in this question,
Corrected reticulocyte count=9 x (5/15) = 3%.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 435.

questions.text: Gottron's papules are seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
• DERMATOMYOSITIS—A rare inflammatory disease characterised by typical skin lesions and weakness of proximal group of muscles.
  • Gottron's papules are violaceous flat-topped papules affecting MCP and IP Joints.

Clinical features of Dermatomyositis:

1. CUTANEOUS SIGNS:
 
  • Gottron's papules:
    • Raised, scaly, erythematous or violaceous papules over the knuckles, elbows, knees, or other extensor surfaces.
  • Gottron's sign:
    • Erythematous or violaceous macules or patches over the same extensor areas without raised papules.
  • Heliotrope rash:
    • Violaceous discoloration with or without edema over the eyelids, often accompanied by periorbital edema.
  • Shawl sign:
    • Erythematous or violaceous rash over the upper back, shoulders, or chest, resembling a shawl distribution.
  • V-sign:
    • Rash on the upper chest and neck in a V-shaped distribution.
  • Mechanic's hands:
    • Hyperkeratotic, cracked skin on the lateral and palmar aspects of the fingers, resembling a mechanic’s hands.
  • Photosensitivity:
    • Rashes in sun-exposed areas, aggravated by UV light.

2. MUSCLE WEAKNESS:
 
  • Proximal muscle weakness:
    • Involves the shoulders, hips, and neck flexors, making activities like climbing stairs, rising from a chair, or lifting objects difficult.
    • Typically painless, although mild myalgias may occur.

3. SYSTEMIC FEATURES:
 
  • Interstitial lung disease (ILD):
    • Can occur in up to 30% of patients. Symptoms include cough and dyspnea.
  • Dysphagia:
    • Due to esophageal muscle involvement.
  • Arthritis:
    • Non-erosive polyarthritis is sometimes present.

4. ASSOCIATED FEATURES;
 
  • Dermatomyositis can be a paraneoplastic syndrome, associated with malignancies such as ovarian, lung, pancreatic, or gastric cancer.

5. NAILFOLD ABNORMALITIES;
 
  • Dilated capillary loops or dropouts, periungual erythema, and telangiectasias seen in the nailfold area.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2819, 2820.

questions.text: Which of the following presents with vesicular lesions?
questions.solution:
Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an acute viral illness that presents as a vesicular eruption in the mouth, but it can also involve the hands, feet, buttocks, and/or genitalia.
 
  • Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) is caused by Coxsackievirus A16 (most common) or enterovirus 71. It presents with characteristic vesicular lesions on the hands, feet, and sometimes on the buttocks and mouth. The lesions are typically small, red, and blister-like (vesicular), often appearing after a few days of fever and malaise.

Other options:
 

  1. Roseola (Sixth Disease):

    • Caused by Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6), this illness is characterized by a high fever followed by a maculopapular rash, not vesicular lesions.

  2. Dengue:

    • Dengue fever typically presents with maculopapular or petechial rash, not vesicular lesions. The rash can be more severe in cases of dengue hemorrhagic fever.

  3. Zika:

    • Zika virus infection is typically associated with a maculopapular rash (not vesicular), along with other symptoms like fever, conjunctivitis, and joint pain.



Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 483, 497, 498.

questions.solution:

  • It is a benign self­ limiting viral infection of epidermal keratinocytes.
  • It leads to pearly white, dome shaped umbilicated papule, generally over the face.
  • It shows Pseudo- koebner's phenomenon - Appearances of morphologically similar lesions along line of trauma (stretching).

questions.text: Black eschar on the back is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Black Eschar is seen in Scrub typhus aka - Chiggerosis.
  • Causative agent—Orientia tsutsugamushi
  • Vector— Chiggers (Trombiculid mite)
  • Symptoms —Fever, headache, myalgia, generalised /regional Lymphadenopathy.
 
  • Scrub typhus, caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi, is characterized by a black eschar at the site of the mite bite, which is a characteristic feature of the disease. This eschar typically appears on the back, chest, or limbs, and is often surrounded by an erythematous halo. The disease is endemic in areas of Asia, Africa, and parts of the Pacific.

Other options:
 

  1. RMSF (Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever):

    • RMSF caused by Rickettsia rickettsii presents with a maculopapular or petechial rash, not a black eschar. Rash often starts on the wrists and ankles and may spread to the palms and soles.

  2. Covid-19:

    • Covid-19 does not typically present with a black eschar. It primarily causes respiratory symptoms, fever, and a wide range of other systemic symptoms, including skin manifestations, but not eschar.

  3. Malaria:

    • Malaria, caused by the Plasmodium species, presents with cyclical fever, chills, and sweating. It does not cause a black eschar.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 415.

questions.text:
A 52 year old chronic alcoholic for last many years with daily drinking habits, comes to emergency with H/O Seizures auditory hallucinations and 2° dilutions. His last drink was 2 days back. Choose the most appropriate management:
I. Diazepam 
II. Naltrexone
III. Inj. Thiamine 
IV. Inj. Flupenthixol
questions.solution:
Scenario is suggestive of Delirium tremens.
 
  • Naltrexone (anti-craving) is given after withdrawal is over.
  • Flupenthixol is long-acting antipsychotic depot injection not required in this case.
  • Drug of choice for alcohol withdrawal is Benzodiazepines 
  • Thiamine is given to prevent Wernicke's encephalopathy.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3561, 3562.

Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page no 631, 632.

questions.text: A patient with chronic alcohol use (around 1 bottle of whisky daily), stopped consuming alcohol for 2 days. He was brought to emergency, on investigation, LFTs were deranged. Which of the following should be given for detoxification?
questions.solution:
The correct option for detoxification in a patient with chronic alcohol use and deranged LFT after stopping alcohol for 2 days is Lorazepam, which is option 3.
  • Lorazepam is particularly useful in patients with liver disease, as it is metabolized by glucuronidation rather than by the liver, which reduces the risk of toxicity.

Other options:
 
  • Option 1: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication that is not used for detoxification in alcohol-dependent patients. It is used to treat psychotic disorders and agitation.
 
  • Option 2 : Chlordiazepoxide, is a benzodiazepine that is also commonly used for alcohol detoxification. However, in patients with liver disease, it can accumulate and cause toxicity, so lorazepam is preferred.
 
  • Option 4 : Diazepam, is another benzodiazepine that is used for alcohol detoxification. However, it is metabolized by the liver, so it may not be the best choice for patients with liver disease.

Therefore, based on the given scenario, Lorazepam is the best choice for detoxification in this patient.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 311, 342-345.

questions.text: Therapeutic dose of Lithium in acute mania?
questions.solution:
Lithium therapeutic dose:
  • Acute Mania : 0.8 -1.2 mEq/L
  • Prophylaxis : 0.5-0.8 mEq/L
If Li+ conc.>1.5 m Eq/L, it produces toxicity.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 377.

questions.text: All of the following are relative contraindication for BCS except?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Basal type of breast cancer?

Basal type, also referred as Triple Negative Breast Ca or TNBC is negative for ER, PR and HER2neu.

  1. Luminal A [Double positive]: ER(+), PR(+), HER-2-NEU (-) : Best prognosis
  2. Luminal B [Triple positive]: ER(+), PR(+), HER-2-NEU (+)

questions.text: Which drug is used in goiter patients to reduce bleeding before thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
• Lugol's iodine is used in goiter patients before thyroidectomy to reduce vascularity and bleeding during surgery.
  • It works by inhibiting the release of thyroid hormones (Wolff-Chaikoff effect) and reducing the gland's blood flow, making it less vascular and easier to operate on. This is especially beneficial in cases of hyperthyroid goiter.
  • Lugol's Iodine is started 1-10 days prior to surgery to decrease vascularity of gland and thus chances of intraoperative thyroid storm.


Pre-operative preparation of a hyperthyroid patient

1. Antithyroid medication:
  • Drugs: Propylthiouracil (PTU) or Methimazole.
  • Purpose: To inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis and control hyperthyroid symptoms.
  • Duration: Typically started weeks before surgery to achieve a euthyroid state.
  • Monitoring: Regular checks of thyroid hormone levels (T3, T4, TSH) to ensure normalization.

2. Beta blockers:
  • Drug: Propranolol (commonly used).
  • Purpose: To control symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as tachycardia, palpitations, and tremors.
  • Dose: Adjusted based on symptom control.

3. Iodine therapy:
  • Drug: Lugol's iodine or potassium iodide.
  • Purpose: To reduce thyroid vascularity, gland size, and hormone release (Wolff-Chaikoff effect).
  • Timing: Typically given 7–10 days before surgery.

4. Corticosteroids:
  • Drug: Hydrocortisone or Betamethasone.
  • Purpose:
    • To reduce the risk of adrenal insufficiency if hyperthyroidism is severe or prolonged.
    • To stabilize thyroid function and decrease inflammation.

5. Co-morbidities:
  • Address any underlying cardiovascular issues, such as atrial fibrillation.
  • Optimize nutritional status and hydration.

6. Anxiolytics:
  • Drug: Benzodiazepines.
  • Purpose: To alleviate anxiety, which can exacerbate hyperthyroid symptoms.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 813.

questions.text: Identify the pink segment shown in imaging?
questions.solution:
Section of CT showing various segments of liver.

Based on the image provided, the pink segment shown is Segment 5.
  • Liver is divided into eight segments based on the Couinaud classification system, which is based on the distribution of the hepatic veins and bile ducts.
  • Segment 5 is located in the left lobe of the liver and is supplied by the left hepatic artery and portal vein. It is also drained by the left hepatic vein.
  • The other segments are located in the right lobe of the liver.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 1162, 1163.

questions.text: Which of the following is false in case of acute cholecystitis?
questions.solution:
HIDA Scan is Gold standard for diagnosis of acute cholecystitis. (Finding: Non-visualization of GB in acute cholecystitis).
 
  • Triad of acute cholecystitis: Right upper quadrant pain, Fever, Leucocytosis.
  • Murphy's sign is elicited in patients with acute cholecystitis by asking the patient to take in and hold a deep breath while palpating the right subcostal area. If pain occurs when the inflamed gallbladder comes into contact with the examiner's hand, Murphy's sign is positive.
  • It is positive in acute cholecystitis
 
  • Imaging:
    • Ultrasound: Gallbladder wall thickening (>3 mm), pericholecystic fluid, and sonographic Murphy's sign.
    • HIDA scan: Non-visualization of the gallbladder due to obstruction of the cystic duct.
 
  • Lab findings: Leukocytosis, elevated inflammatory markers (CRP), and sometimes mild liver enzyme elevation.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 212, 213, 1199, 1200.

questions.text: After appendectomy, exploration was done for bleeding, ligation of which artery is beneficial?
questions.solution:
• In an appendectomy, bleeding typically arises from vessels supplying the appendix. The appendicular artery, a branch of the ileocolic artery (which itself is a branch of the superior mesenteric artery), is the primary blood supply to the appendix.
 
  • If there is significant bleeding post-appendectomy, ligation of the ileocolic artery would be beneficial as it controls blood flow to the appendicular artery and the surrounding region.

Arterial supply of Appendix:
 




Other options:

  1. Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA):
    Ligation of the SMA would lead to catastrophic ischemia of large portions of the intestine. It is not specific to the appendix.

  2. Right Colic Artery:
    The right colic artery supplies the ascending colon, not the appendix directly. Ligation would not effectively control bleeding from the appendicular region.

  3. Middle Colic Artery:
    The middle colic artery supplies the transverse colon and is unrelated to the appendicular vasculature.




Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1300, 1301.

questions.text: Boot shaped heart with history of cyanosis is seen with which of the following?
questions.solution:
X ray shows Boot-shaped heart : classical finding of TOF.
 

A boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray is a classic finding in Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). It results from the right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH), which elevates the apex of the heart and creates the characteristic appearance.


Features of ToF

  1. Cyanosis: Caused by right-to-left shunting of blood through the ventricular septal defect (VSD) due to pulmonary stenosis.
  2. Key anatomical defects:
    • Pulmonary stenosis.
    • VSD.
    • Overriding aorta.
    • Right ventricular hypertrophy.
  3. X-ray findings:
    • Boot-shaped heart (from RVH).
    • Oligemic lung fields (reduced pulmonary blood flow).


Other options:
 

  1. TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries):

    • Cyanosis is present, but the X-ray shows an egg-on-a-string appearance, not a boot-shaped heart.

  2. Ebstein's Anomaly:

    • Enlarged right atrium, a "box-shaped" heart, not boot-shaped. Cyanosis may occur but is less common.

  3. TAPVC (Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection):

    • Cyanosis is present, and X-ray may show a snowman sign in supracardiac TAPVC, not a boot-shaped heart.



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 2406.

Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 417, 420, 423, 424.

questions.text:
A pt. came to the emergency with Abdominal pain, H/O chronic NSAID use, X-ray shown below. What will be next steps in management of this patient?

(i) CECT 
(ii) IV fluids 
(iii) Exploratory lap 
(iv) UGIE
questions.solution:
• IV fluids (ii) and exploratory laparotomy (iii) are the essential next steps in this emergency situation to stabilize and definitively treat the patient.
  • CECT (i) may not be practical in an unstable patient.
  • UGIE (iv) is not indicated in acute perforation scenarios.

Steps in management:
 

  1. Immediate Resuscitation (Critical Priority):

    • IV fluids: Start aggressive fluid resuscitation to manage hypovolemia due to potential peritonitis and sepsis.
    • Monitor vitals and assess hemodynamic stability.

  2. Emergency Surgical Intervention:

    • Exploratory laparotomy (or laparoscopy): This is the definitive step to locate and repair the perforation. Delay in surgery increases morbidity and mortality.

  3. Imaging (if patient is stable):

    • In hemodynamically stable patients, CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT) can be performed to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of the perforation or other intra-abdominal pathology. However, in unstable patients, imaging is bypassed for immediate surgery.

  4. UGIE (Upper Gastrointestinal Endoscopy):

    • Typically not done in acute perforation cases as it is contraindicated due to the risk of worsening the condition. It may be considered later to evaluate the underlying cause of the ulcer.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1048, 1050-1052.

questions.text: In RTA case, whole body CT scan will not include which of the following?
questions.solution:
In cases of road traffic accidents (RTA), a whole-body CT scan, also called a trauma CT, is performed as part of the advanced trauma life support (ATLS) protocol to assess for life-threatening injuries. It typically includes:

  1. CT Brain: To evaluate for head injuries, including intracranial hemorrhages or skull fractures.
  2. CT Spine: To assess for spinal injuries, which are common in high-energy trauma.
  3. CT Abdomen and Pelvis: To identify internal organ damage, bleeding, or fractures.

CT Upper Limb is not routinely included in a whole-body trauma CT scan because it is less likely to be life-threatening. Upper limb injuries are generally evaluated with targeted imaging (e.g., X-rays or regional CT) if clinically indicated.


Whole-body CT scan includes:

  • Head: To assess brain injuries.
  • Neck: Includes cervical spine and soft tissues.
  • Chest: For thoracic injuries, lung contusions, and rib fractures.
  • Abdomen and Pelvis: For solid organ and vascular injuries.
  • Spine: Cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine.

Peripheral limb imaging is not part of routine trauma CT unless specifically required.




Reference: Jones J, O'Shea P, Murphy A, et al. Whole-body CT (protocol). Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 04 Dec 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-9051. URL: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/whole-body-ct-protocol

questions.text:
Match the following 
a. Rat tail sign 1. TB
b. String sign  2. Pneumoperitoneum
c. Inverted umbrella 3. Pyloric stenosis
d. Football sign 4. CA esophagus
questions.solution:
• The Rat's tail sign refers to tapering of the inferior esophagus on barium swallow study. Many sources use this sign synonymously with the bird beak sign (esophagus) and indicate that it is characteristic of achalasia or pyloric stenosis.
 
  • The String sign refers to luminal narrowing as the result of inflammatory edema, irritability, spasms and fibrosis classically associated within Crohn's disease. This sign is not always pathognomonic for Crohn's disease, and the differential diagnosis includes tuberculosis and carcinoma.
 
  • The Fleischner sign (also known as the inverted umbrella sign), refers to a widely gaping, thickened, patulous ileocecal valve and a narrowed, ulcerated terminal ileum associated with tuberculous involvement of the ileocecum.
 
  • The Football sign is seen in cases of massive pneumoperitoneum, where the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas from a perforated viscus.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1122.

Shetty A, Weerakkody Y, Vibhakar A, et al. Fleischner sign (tuberculosis of ileocecal junction). Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 04 Dec 2024) https://radiopaedia.org/articles/27632

choices.text: Muscle relaxant and induction agent is given simultaneously
Method of choice for cardiac arrest patients
Tubes with low pressure and high-volume cuffs are used

questions.text: Not true about Rapid Sequence Intubation (RSI) is:
questions.solution:
RSI is a technique primarily used for emergency airway management in patients who are conscious or semiconscious with a risk of aspiration. It is not suitable for patients in cardiac arrest, as sedation and muscle relaxation are unnecessary in that scenario.
 

  • Pre-oxygenation with 100% O2 for 3 minutes: (Option 1)

    • True. Pre-oxygenation is a standard part of rapid sequence intubation (RSI) to increase oxygen reserves and reduce the risk of hypoxia during apnea.
 

  • Muscle relaxant and induction agent is given simultaneously: (Option 2)

    • True. In RSI, an induction agent (e.g., propofol, etomidate) and a rapid-onset muscle relaxant (e.g., succinylcholine, rocuronium) are given back-to-back without bag-mask ventilation to minimize aspiration risk.
 

  • Method of choice for cardiac arrest patients: (Option 3)

    • False. RSI is not typically used in cardiac arrest because patients are already unresponsive and do not require sedatives or muscle relaxants. Instead, direct intubation or other airway management techniques are used.
 

  • Tubes with low pressure and high-volume cuffs are used: (Option 4)

    • True. Endotracheal tubes with low-pressure, high-volume cuffs are preferred to ensure a proper seal, reduce the risk of aspiration, and minimize tracheal damage.



Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1382.

questions.text:
A patient was found lying unconscious. Choose the correct sequence of management? 
(a) Chest compression 
(b) Bap and Mask ventilation 
(c) Check Pulse 
(d) Check Response 
Choose the correct sequence:
questions.solution:
This sequence is based on the basic life support (BLS) guidelines recommended by the American Heart Association (AHA) and other organizations.
  • The first step is to check the response of the patient, followed by checking for pulse.
  • If there is no response or pulse, then the next step is to perform chest compression to maintain circulation.
  • Once the circulation is established, the next step is to provide bag and mask ventilation to support breathing. 





Reference: Adult Basic Life Support Algorithm, AHA 2020 guidelines. URL: https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms

questions.text: Which nerve is injured when a person is injured at point 'X' on the leg and presents with a foot drop to the emergency?
questions.solution:
• Injury to common peroneal nerve leads to foot drop.
  • Common peroneal nerve injury is common in Fracture of Neck of fibula.
  • Affected muscles include Anterior & Lateral compartment muscles.
  • There is Loss of Dorsiflexion of ankle joint - Foot drop (Deep peroneal Nerve> Common peroneal N), Loss of Eversion and Loss of extension of Toes.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 1415, 1416.

questions.text: Book test is done for testing which of the following nerve?
questions.solution:
Book Test is done to test adductor pollicis muscle supplied by ulnar Nerve.
 
  • The test evaluates the integrity of the adductor pollicis muscle, which is innervated by the ulnar nerve.
 
  • During the test, the patient is asked to hold a book or similar object between their thumb and index finger. If the ulnar nerve is compromised, the patient may struggle to adduct the thumb properly and may compensate by flexing the thumb using the flexor pollicis longus (innervated by the median nerve), resulting in a Froment's sign.



Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 296.

questions.text: You are called to a new born baby's house to look at the baby, you notice CTEV, At what age will you advice the baby's parents to get the cast correction for CTEV?
questions.solution:
• Initial treatment starts with Ponsetti’s POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year age.
  • If deformity gets corrected, Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age.
  • After 1 year up to 5 years, CTEV shoes are used in day & Dennis brown splint used at night, if deformity is not corrected or untreated previously.




Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 614-616.

questions.text: Positive Tredelenburg test on right side, where is the lesion?
questions.solution:
• The given scenario is suggestive of Superior Gluteal nerve on Left side injury, paralysis of gluteus medius & gluteus minimus muscles of left side is seen.
 
  • When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius & minimus  muscles, on opposite supported side, exert traction on hip bone by acting from femur.
 
  • This action results in the slight raising of pelvis on unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in upright position
 
  • When the gluteus medius & minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on unsupported (normal) side when pt. tries to stand on affected Limb.



Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 234, 548.

questions.text: What is the characteristic clinical feature seen in Klumpke's palsy?
questions.solution:
When the ulnar and median nerves get damaged, muscles in the forearm override the action of the lumbricals, causing the hand to look like a claw. So, with Klumpke's palsy, patient’s forearm is stuck in the supinated position, with the wrist extended.
 

Klumpke's palsy is caused by injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8 and T1 nerve roots). This affects the ulnar nerve and, to some extent, the median nerve, leading to characteristic symptoms:

  1. Claw hand deformity:

    • Due to paralysis of the intrinsic hand muscles (lumbricals and interossei) innervated by the ulnar and median nerves.
    • Results in hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexion of the interphalangeal (IP) joints, especially in the 4th and 5th fingers.

  2. Weakness in hand grip:

    • Paralysis of the flexor muscles of the fingers and intrinsic hand muscles.

  3. Sensory deficits:

    • Loss of sensation along the medial arm, forearm, and hand (ulnar side).

  4. Horner's syndrome (occasionally):

    • If the T1 nerve root involvement extends to the sympathetic fibers, symptoms like ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis may occur.



Reference: BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy- Volume I, 8th edition, Page no 62, 63, 109, 201.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for Vulvar cancer?
questions.solution:
The risk factors for vulvar cancer include smoking, human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, vulvar dystrophy, and lichen sclerosus.
  • Vulval hamartomas are not considered a risk factor for vulvar cancer.

Risk factors for Vulval CA:
 
  1. Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection
  2. Smoking
  3. Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN)
  4. Vulvar dystrophies (e.g., lichen sclerosus)
  5. Immunosuppression (e.g., HIV, immunosuppressive drugs)
  6. Advanced age
  7. Chronic vulvar inflammation or irritation
  8. History of cervical, vaginal, or anal cancer
  9. Obesity
  10. Diabetes
  11. Early sexual activity
  12. Multiple sexual partners



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition Page no 473, 475.

questions.text: Most common age group for vulvar cancer is ?
questions.solution:
• The incidence of vulvar cancer increases with age, and it is most commonly diagnosed in women over the age of 60.
  • Vulvar cancer is most common in postmenopausal women, with the peak incidence occurring in the 6th to 8th decades of life.
 
  • However, HPV-associated vulvar cancers can occur in younger women (30–50 years), but these are less common compared to the overall incidence in older age groups.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition Page no 475-477.

questions.text: An in-utero exposure to Diethyl stilbestrol (DES) can lead to which type of carcinoma in the daughter?
questions.solution:
Exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) during fetal development can lead to clear cell carcinoma of the vagina in female offspring.
 
  • Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic estrogen that was used during pregnancy in the mid-20th century to prevent miscarriage and other complications.
  • In daughters exposed to DES in utero (referred to as DES daughters), there is an increased risk of developing clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina or cervix, often presenting in their late teens or early adulthood.
  • The vaginal adenosis (replacement of squamous epithelium with glandular epithelium) caused by DES exposure is a precursor lesion for this carcinoma.


Other options:
 
  1. Sarcoma botryoides: A rare embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, unrelated to DES exposure.
  2. Squamous cell carcinoma of the vagina: Typically occurs in older women, not linked to DES exposure.
  3. Basal cell carcinoma: A skin malignancy, not related to DES.



Reference: William's Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 45, 108, 424, 691.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is secreted by the placenta?
questions.solution:
• Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is made almost exclusively in the placenta.
 
  • hCG hormone levels found in the mother's blood and urine rise a lot during the first trimester.

Hormones secreted by Placenta:
 
  1. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
  2. Human placental lactogen (hPL)
  3. Progesterone
  4. Estrogens (primarily estriol)
  5. Relaxin
  6. Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH)
  7. Growth factors (e.g., epidermal growth factor)



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 53, 54.

choices.text: Starts with or after contraction but ends always after contraction
Nadir of deceleration and peak of contraction do not coincide

questions.text: All are true about late deceleration except?
questions.solution:
Late decelerations are typically uniform in shape and duration, lasting longer than 30 seconds and returning to baseline after the contraction has ended.
  • Variable decelerations, on the other hand, are variable in shape, duration, and timing, and are usually caused by umbilical cord compression.

Late decelerations in cardiotocography (CTG) are characterized by: (Options)

  1. Starts with or after the contraction and ends after the contraction: True. Late decelerations occur after the onset of uterine contraction and resolve after the contraction ends.
  2. Occurs due to utero-placental insufficiency: True. They are caused by impaired oxygen transfer from the placenta to the fetus.
  3. Nadir of deceleration and peak of contraction do not coincide: True. The nadir (lowest point) of the deceleration occurs after the peak of the contraction.
  4. It is usually variable & short: False. Late decelerations are uniform and have a gradual onset and offset, typically lasting longer than variable decelerations.



Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 451, 452.

questions.text: All of the following seen in abruptio placenta except?
questions.solution:
Painless bleeding in seen in Placenta Previa.
 

Abruptio placenta (placental abruption) typically presents with the following characteristics:

  1. Uterine tenderness: Common due to the placental separation causing uterine irritation.
  2. Increased uterine tone: Often seen because of uterine contractions that accompany placental separation.
  3. Abdominal pain: A hallmark of placental abruption, as it leads to significant uterine contractions and pain.

However, painless bleeding is not a characteristic of abruptio placenta. Painless bleeding is more commonly seen in placenta previa, where the placenta is located over the cervix. Abruptio placenta is typically associated with painful bleeding due to the abrupt separation of the placenta from the uterine wall.



Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 749-753, 755.

questions.text:
Arrange in sequence, the steps in 3rd stage of management of labour? 
(a) Check for 2nd baby 
(b) Oxytocin 10 units 
(c) Controlled cord traction 
(d) Uterine message
questions.solution:
AMTSL(Active management of third stage of labour):
Done in all females in Labour and is the best method to prevent PPH.

Components:
  1. Injecting utero tonic to mother after delivery of baby (Most Imp. step)
  2. Delayed cord clamping
  3. Deliver placenta by controlled cord traction: Modified Brandt Andrew's technique
  4. Intermittent assessment of uterine tone.
Uterine Massage is a part of treatment PPH.



Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 507.

questions.text: Which is wrong about normal Placenta?
questions.solution:
In a normal pregnancy, the placenta has two arteries and one vein, which make up the umbilical cord.

A normal placenta typically contains:

  • 2 arteries (one for carrying deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta)
  • 1 vein (which carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus)


Other options:
 
  1. Weight: The average weight of a normal placenta is about 500 grams.
  2. Diameter: The average diameter is around 20 cm.
  3. Thickness: The average thickness of a normal placenta is about 2.5 cm.



Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 108, 109.

questions.text:
The sign seen at 8 weeks of pregnancy are: 
(a) Goodell's sign 
(b) Osiander sign
(c) Lightening 
(d) Internal ballottment
questions.solution:
• The Goodell sign refers to a probable sign of pregnancy, characterized by softening of the cervix. A positive Goodell sign occurs due to increased blood flow noticed in the cervix during the first 4 to 8 weeks of pregnancy, which can also give the vaginal part of the cervix a bluish appearance (Chadwick sign).
 
  • Osiander’s sign is an early indication of pregnancy (at eight weeks) in which pulsation can be felt through the lateral vaginal fornix.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 61, 65.

Manage with increased iron content in diet

questions.text: As per Anemia Mukt Bharat, how is mild-moderate anemia treated in a pregnant woman of less than 34 weeks gestational age?
questions.solution:
Parental iron (IV Iron Sucrose or FCM) may be considered as the first line of management in pregnant women who are detected to be anemic late in pregnancy or in whom compliance is likely to be low (high chance of lost to follow-up).
  • According to operational guidelines of Anemia Mukt Bharat, mild to moderate cases of anemia in pregnant women are initially treated with 2 tablets of IFA.
  • If there is no response, IV iron sucrose is to given.



Reference: Anaemia Mukt Bharat scheme, National Health Mission, GoI guidelines (2018). URL: https://nhm.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=3&sublinkid=1448&lid=797

questions.text: Which is not a component of the biophysical profile?
questions.solution:
Biophysical score Aka Hanning score. It is done with help of USG Done over 30 mins.

It has 5 components:
  1. Fetal tone = In 30 mins, 1 episode of fetal extension - flexion
  2. Fetal breathing movement ( 1 breathing movement x 30 secs)
  3. Gross body movements of fetus =3 body movements
  4. Single largest vertical Pocket of amniotic fluid 2cm
  5. NST: Reactive.
 
  • Each parameter is given a score of either 0/2
  • If total score= 8 or 10/10: Healthy pt.
  • Score 6 /10 or less = Reassessment after 2 weeks
  • <6/10 on reassessment= Fetal hypoxia.




Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 389, 390.

questions.text:
Match the following 
Drug Adverse/Teratogenic effect
(1) Thalidomide A. Grey baby syndrome
(2) Isotretinoin B. Ebstein's anomaly
(3) Chloramphenicol C. Depressed nasal bridge

questions.text: What is the usual timing when this procedure can be done?
questions.solution:
• The image shown above depicts Amniocentesis.
 
  • Amniocentesis is usually carried out between the 16th and 20th weeks of pregnancy.
 
  • Amniocentesis is a prenatal procedure that your doctor may recommend you have during pregnancy. The test checks for fetal abnormalities (birth defects) such as Down syndrome, cystic fibrosis or spina bifida.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 741.

questions.text:
Recombinant HPV vaccine is based on which viral protein? 
1. L1 
2. L2
3. E1 , E2
4. E6, E7
questions.solution:
• HPV vaccine is a non-infectious recombinant vaccine prepared from the purified virus-like particles (VLPs) of the major capsid (L1) protein of HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.
 
  • The recombinant HPV vaccine is based on the L1 protein, which is the major capsid protein of the human papillomavirus (HPV).
  • The L1 protein is expressed in yeast cells to produce virus-like particles (VLPs), which mimic the outer structure of the virus.
  • These VLPs are used in the vaccine to stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies against HPV, thereby preventing infection.
 
  • L2 is the minor capsid protein but is not the primary target for the recombinant vaccines.
  • E1, E2, E6, and E7 are other proteins involved in HPV replication and oncogenesis but are not the basis for the current vaccines.



Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th edition, Page no 647-650.

questions.text: An NCCT scan was suggested for a lady of reproductive age. She presented with a history of recent and rapid-onset headaches. Which of the following enquires need to be made by the radiology technician prior to the scan?
questions.solution:
• Pregnancy needs to be ruled out before performing NCCT in a woman of reproductive age group.
  • It’s important to assess the possibility of pregnancy in women of reproductive age, as certain imaging modalities should be approached with caution or avoided in pregnant patients to avoid radiation induced risks to the fetus.
 
  • Pregnancy: Exposure to radiation during the early stages of pregnancy can pose a risk to the fetus, especially during the first trimester. It is important to rule out pregnancy to ensure the safety of the patient and the fetus.
  • If there is any chance the patient could be pregnant, alternative imaging methods (such as MRI) or shielding may be considered.


Other options:
 
  • History of fall: Not specifically relevant for assessing risks related to the CT scan procedure.
  • History of hypertension: While important for clinical management, it does not directly impact the safety of a non-contrast CT scan.
  • Cochlear implant: Not a concern for non-contrast CT scans as CT scans do not use magnetic fields like MRI. However, this would be important to consider before an MRI scan.



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 479, 736, 817.

questions.text: Which of the following is not indicated in 1st trimester MTP/Abortion?
questions.solution:
The use of extra-amniotic ethacridine lactate provides an effective and safe treatment method for second trimester legal abortion.
  • Abortion methods in first trimester:
  1. Medical Abortion (Mifepristone + Misoprostol)
  2. Suction & Evacuation
  3. MVA.

questions.text:
What is the right sequence of events of labour? 
(i) Engagement 
(ii) Restitution 
(iii) External Rotation 
(iv) Crowning
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events during labor is as follows:

1. Engagement: This is the first stage of labor where the fetal head descends into the pelvic cavity and gets fixed in the maternal pelvis.
2. Crowning: This is the second stage of labor where the widest part of the fetal head distends the vulva just before delivery.
3. Restitution: This is the third stage of labor where the fetal head rotates back to its original position in line with the fetal body.
4. External Rotation: This is the final stage of labor where the fetal shoulders rotate to the anteroposterior position and the baby is delivered.






Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 420.

questions.text: A woman who presented with seizures at 30 weeks of pregnancy was started on MgSO4 therapy. What would be the first sign of MgSO4 toxicity seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
• MgSO4 is the DOC for management of pre-eclampsia & Eclampsia.
  • 1st sign of MgSO4 Toxicity : Absence of knee jerks (Levels >10 mEq/L).

Other signs :
  • Diaphoresis, Flushing, Slurring of speech.
  • Respiratory depression : >12 mEq/L
  • Respiratory paralysis : >15mEq/L


Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 719, 720.

questions.text: Identify the image given
questions.solution:
• Cystic teratoma is the most common ovarian neoplasm.
  • It consists of well-differentiated derivatives of all three germ cell layers (i.e., ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm) developing as hair, muscle, teeth, or bone.
  • These tumors are generally benign but may undergo a malignant transformation in 1% to 2% of the cases.
 

Gross Morphological Features of a Mature Cystic Teratoma:

  • Cystic structure: Well-encapsulated, fluid-filled mass.
  • Contents: Hair, sebaceous material, teeth, bone, and sometimes cartilage.
  • Color: Yellowish or creamy due to sebaceous material.
  • External surface: Smooth and shiny.
  • Solid elements: May contain solid areas of cartilage, bone, or teeth.
  • Benign nature: No invasion into surrounding tissues.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 16th edition Page no 446.

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of events in Dilatation & Curettage (D&C) ? 
(i) Uterine sound 
(ii) Serial dilatations 
(iii) Curettage
(iv) Determining the size of the uterus
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events for Dilation and Curettage (D&C) procedure is: (iv)-(i)-(ii)-(iii)
  1. Determining the size of the uterus: This is usually done by performing a pelvic examination or an ultrasound.
  2. Uterine sound: Once the size of the uterus is determined, a uterine sound is used to measure the depth of the uterus. The sound is a long, thin, and flexible rod that is inserted into the uterus through the cervix.
  3. Serial dilatations: After measuring the depth of the uterus, serial dilatations are performed to widen the cervix. This is done by inserting progressively larger dilators into the cervix until it is wide enough to allow the curette to pass through.
  4. Curettage: Once the cervix is dilated, a curette is inserted into the uterus to remove the lining of the uterus.



Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 210, 211, 239.

questions.text: Which of the following is meaning of the term Vagitus uterinus?
questions.solution:
• Vagitus uterinus refers to the cry of a fetus within the uterus, which can sometimes be heard in cases of fetal distress.
 
  • This term is associated with the occurrence of fetal sounds, such as crying, due to distress or certain pathological conditions during pregnancy.



Reference: Matthiasson, Heingrimur. “Vagitus Uterinus.” British Medical Journal vol. 1,3770 (1933): 632. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2368192/

questions.text: A 16 year old girl presented to the OPD with a webbed neck shield chest, widely spaced nipple and absent pubic hair. Streak ovaries were revealed on USG. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Turner’s syndrome : 45 XO

Features:
  • Short stature
  • Triangular face
  • Neck: Loose skin folds and Webbed neck
  • Chest : Shield (flat) chest & widely spaced nipples.
  • Increased carrying angle = >135° i.e. Cubitus vagus
  • Heart defects : Bicuspid aortic valve > Coarctation of Aorta.
  • IQ : normal.





Reference: Nelson's Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 669, 3003.

questions.text: Which of the following method of contraception is irreversible?
questions.solution:
Sterilization is an irreversible method of contraception, typically involving surgical procedures such as tubal ligation in women or vasectomy in men. These procedures are designed to permanently prevent pregnancy.


Other options:

  1. Injectable contraception: Reversible method, involves hormone injections for temporary contraception.
  2. Implants: Reversible method, hormonal implants are placed under the skin and can be removed.
  3. IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device): Reversible method, it can be inserted and removed by a healthcare provider.


Reference: William's Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 114-118.

questions.solution:
Primary amenorrhea—

  • M/C type of Gonadal dysgenesis—Turner's syndrome

questions.text: Which of these is not an alternative way to measure height in a 4 year old boy?
questions.solution:
Head circumference (option 1) is not a measure of height.
 
  • Knee height can be used as a surrogate to measure height where the child sits on a stool and Length/ height of knee from ground is taken, but it is not used commonly. 
  • Arm span in a child is a surrogate marker of height (Arm span is equal to height at 10-11 years of age and later arm span is more than height by only 1-12 cm) and can be used as an Alternative way to measure height.
  • Stadiometer is an instrument which is used to measure height of child after 2 years of age.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 151, 881.

questions.text: Handedness is established by?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option (1) 3 years.

Handedness, or the preference for using one hand over the other, is typically established around the age of 3 years.
However, it becomes more pronounced and stable as the child grows, with clearer hand preference emerging by 4-5 years.  

Important milestones attained by a 3-year-old child
  • Climb stairs upwards by 1 feet/step
  • Develops Handedness
  • Make a 9 Block Tower
  • Knows Name, Age, Gender
  • Ride Tricycle
  • Copies circle


A few single-liners frequently tested in exams:
  • 3-5 months – HAND REGARD.
  • 4 months - BINOCULAR VISION
  • 4-6 months – MOUTHING
  • 9 months – OBJECT PERMANENCE
  • 1 year – CASTING – Deliberately throwing objects to the ground
  • 3 years – HANDEDNESS – Child starts using one hand for daily use


Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 143.

choices.text: Both A, R correct and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A ,R correct and R is NOT the correct explanation of A

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Mousy odor is seen in urine of patients with phenyl ketonuria
Reason (R): Decrease in serum levels of tyrosine, dopamine and norepinephrine
questions.solution:
• The musty or mousy odor of urine in phenylketonuria (PKU) results from the buildup of phenylalanine metabolites, such as phenylpyruvate, phenylacetate, and phenyl lactate.
 
  • PKU can cause reduced levels of tyrosine, which is normally produced from phenylalanine. Tyrosine is a precursor for catecholamines like dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine, so low tyrosine levels may lead to a deficiency in these neurotransmitters. However, this is not the cause of the mousy odor in urine.
 
  • PKU arises from a deficiency in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (in classic PKU) or defects in enzymes involved in tetrahydrobiopterin production.
  • These enzyme deficiencies hinder the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine, resulting in elevated phenylalanine levels and low tyrosine levels.
  • The excess phenylalanine is converted into phenyl ketones (such as phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate), which are then excreted in the urine.



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 695-698.

Lippincott Illustrated Reviews: Biochemistry, 7th edition, Page no 779-786.

questions.text: Not correct about parvovirus B19 infection
questions.solution:
Parvovirus B19 infection is associated with several clinical manifestations, but erosive arthritis is not typically seen in pregnancy.
 

  1. Children - Slapped cheek appearance of rash: Correct. Parvovirus B19 causes fifth disease, which presents as a characteristic slapped cheek rash in children, often accompanied by a lacy rash on the body.

  2. In sickle cell anemia - Aplastic crisis: Correct. Parvovirus B19 can lead to aplastic crisis in individuals with sickle cell anemia by infecting erythroid precursors and halting red blood cell production.

  3. In immunodeficient - Pure red cell aplasia: Correct. In immunocompromised individuals, parvovirus B19 infection can lead to pure red cell aplasia, where only red blood cell production is suppressed.

  4. In pregnancy - Erosive arthritis: Incorrect. While parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to fetal hydrops or miscarriage, erosive arthritis is not a typical complication of pregnancy. Erosive arthritis is more often seen in chronic infections or conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, not with parvovirus B19 in pregnancy.


     

Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th edition Page no 460.

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1496.

questions.text: All of the following vaccines against gram-negative organisms are taken before splenectomy except?
questions.solution:
• Pre-splenectomy - Vaccination is done at least 2 weeks prior to elective splenectomy for H. influenza, Meningococcus, Pneumococcus (All three being encapsulated organisms), and Influenza.
  • Vaccine against Typhoid is not recommended prior to splenectomy. 
 

Before splenectomy, vaccines against gram-negative organisms are crucial to protect against infections due to the loss of the spleen's immune function. The vaccines recommended include:

  • H. influenzae type b (Hib): Protection against Haemophilus influenzae type b, which is a gram-negative bacterium.
  • Meningococcal: Protection against Neisseria meningitidis, a gram-negative bacterium.
  • Pneumococcus: Protection against Streptococcus pneumoniae, which, while a gram-positive bacterium, is recommended before splenectomy due to the risk of severe infections.
 

Typhoid vaccine is not typically recommended before splenectomy, as Salmonella typhi (the causative organism of typhoid) is not as commonly associated with life-threatening infections in splenectomized individuals compared to the others listed. However, typhoid vaccination may still be recommended in certain geographic areas or depending on travel history.




Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 133, 223, 230, 333.

Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1230, 1231

questions.text: A child presented with a decreased pulse in the lower limb with delay as compared to pulse felt in the upper limb. What can be the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital condition where there is a narrowing of the aorta, typically in the region of the ductus arteriosus. This narrowing can cause a decrease in blood flow to the lower limbs, leading to:

  • Decreased pulses in the lower limbs, often felt weaker or delayed compared to the upper limbs.
  • Higher blood pressure in the upper limbs compared to the lower limbs.

This discrepancy in pulse is a hallmark sign of coarctation of the aorta, which can be confirmed by imaging studies like echocardiography or MRI.


Other options:
 

  1. TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries): This condition involves the aorta and pulmonary artery being swapped but typically does not cause a pulse discrepancy between upper and lower limbs.

  2. VSD (Ventricular Septal Defect): This is a defect in the heart’s septum and doesn't cause differential pulses between limbs.

  3. TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot): This condition involves four heart defects and typically leads to cyanosis and clubbing, but not a significant discrepancy in pulses between limbs.



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 2389-2391.
